reviewText:
Before you read this review, you should keep in-mind that I've never played a Devil May Cry game before so I don't know how it compares to past games. With that said, DmC: Devil May Cry is a pretty great game with enjoyable gameplay and a surprisingly good story.

THE PROS:
Surpisingly good story that has a mix of seriousness and jokes.
Fun gameplay that has a Stylish" system -- you earn more points by doing combos that uses a variety of different attacks
date: and not just the same moves over and over again.\nAs the story progresses
recommended:
you see Dante go from "not caring" about anything to actually caring about everything.
Great level design full of secrets.
You unlock new weapons/abilties as you progress.
Weapons and abilities can be upgraded with skill points -- or even new abilities can be unlocked with skill points.
Beating the game on higher difficulties will unlock even higher diffculties multiple times
hoursPlayed:
encouraging multiple play-throughs.
Some cool unlockable skins.
Practice mode.
Around 10 hours until you beat the game.

THE MIXED:
Some may find the game kinda repetitive.
Some may also find the game too "try hard" and/or cheesy for their taste.
And of course
voteText: some may not like Dante's new design (however
helpfulPercent:
I am personally fine with it).

THE CONS:
I personally found the final boss fight and ending to be kinda dissapointing.
Some fights are more annoying/tedious than fun.

THE VERDICT:  8.5/10 "Between Great and Amazing"
DmC: Devil May Cry really is a great game

reviewText:
Definitely one of the coolest games I've ever played. I can see many people ♥♥♥♥♥ing about betrayal of the original series... But I think it is a step for the better. I've played through DMC IV before and only thing I found better there was much more complex Dante's gunplay. But apart from that, I've found this game to be better in every conceivable way:

STORY:

Although Dante's attitude in DMC IV and I suppose the previous games was no doubt cool, I found it a little bit too much
anime-y and cliché. In this prequel, Dante is younger, confident, straight-forward, care-free rebel, as lovable as the older himself and much more relatable, mostly because player is able to discover Dante as he discovers himself in the story. The story itself holds together beautifully despite being heavily varied, and story elements like demons, angels and Limbo not only make sense, but they add insane cool factor. Everything in the story works in favor of bringing you the best possible feeling, and that, ladies and gentlemen, is rare.
Character-wise, the cast is not by any means extensive. Besides Dante, his brother Vergil, Vergil's protegeé Kat and four or five antagonists you will sooner or later face as bosses, there is only Phineas, a pacifist blind demon with mechanical eye trapped in Limbo that will help Dante along the way. Other than those are just mindless demons to kill. But don't worry, those few are able to carry to story without any struggle.

GAMEPLAY:

The core of the gameplay is of course the exquisite complex combat system. It is easy to handle, yet tricky to master. There are few basic actions that player controls, and then there are variables, such as timing, chaining combos, which angel or demon weapon is player currently using, which firearm... Player with enough skill can use this system to great depth. It may seem as too much at first, but as you get more and more acquainted with the system, the more sense it makes. You start developing different strategies for different enemies, and most importantly, you'll develop your own style of gameplay. The tools this game offers you can bring a great variety of approaches to defeating your enemies. Having said that, I must also mention that this applies mostly for the meelee weapons, since I felt that firearms were of little significance and power, and besides specific cases, I had no need to use them at all.
Another part of gameplay is platforming. Dante's controls are quite fluent and easy, so if there is any difficulty to platforming, i lies in design, not in controls. The platforming also benefits a great deal from tools such as Angel Lift and Demon Whip, which not only add variety, but also a new dynamic and occasionaly even logic elements, not to mention their use in combat.
When the combat and platforming clash together, a boss fight is born. Boss fights in DMC are a true testament to the gameplay mechanics. Not only are you forced to use a great variety of your skills to even survive them, but you also have to look for bosses' weak spots, come up with specific strategies and really put yourself into the fight.
DmC also relies heavily upon exploration and replayability. Although there is no open world and the way to reach the progression of the story is never more than one, the game offers many side tracks leading to items or challenges. You can also revisit all the locations after you acquire a new set of skills, and try to reach prizes that you were not able to before. A great deal of replayability lies it the many levels of difficulty you can replay the game on and test your skills.

GRAPHICS:

DmC is one of the most beautiful games I, as a graphic designer by trade, ever played. It doesn't rely upon revolutionary, cutting-edge technology (Although its technological level is quite high as well), but rather on style. Majority of actual gameplay happens after Dante is pulled into Limbo, a twisted version of whatever setting he was currently in, where he can utilise all of his nephilim powers. And it is the idea Limbo that allowed the artists and developers of the game bring in the real twisted beauty DmC has to offer. Be it the city rotting under the rule of demons, night club reality changing to the beat of the music or old mansion where Dante and Vergil spent their early childhood, a great amount of detail and thought can be seen anywhere. And not only that, your surroundings can change at any given moment in the story, bringing you a new, breathtaking sight or often fast-paced platforming challenge.
Design of characters and enemies is equally thought out and accordingly twisted. Artists were able to avoid too much cliché in design, yet were able to preserve the feeling any given enemy or boss should emmit. If the Succubus is supposed to be disgusting, be well damn sure it looks disgusting as hell!

SOUND:

The general coolness of the game of course wouldn't be complete without equally cool soundtrack, and it was delivered. Music selected fits the vibe of the game and really helps to increase the immersion. I have nothing more to say about that. Great work on the music.

In conclusion I'd say that DmC is truly a great game. It bring all its elements to nearly perfection. It is unapologetic, cool and action-packed, yet refined and masterfully executed. There are many fans of the original series that are hating the changes, but that is just how some fans are, narrow-minded and blindfolded by the things they love. There is no point in arguing, so don't waste time and rather go play one of the best games of 2013, DmC: Devil May Cry.

9/10

TIPS:

Learn how to use your weapons. Each of them is good for something else. Rebellion is universal, Osiris is great against groups of enemies and also for juggling them in the air, where most of them are helpless, Aquila is weaker than Osiris, but is great at crowd control, since it allows you to pull a number of enemies to you, stagger many enemies in one attack, trap them for a while and even transform dante into tornado of hits that carries enemies along. On the other hand, demon weapons are more fit for fighting single, strong enemies, since they shatter shields and knock back smaller ememies. Arbiter has heavy strikes, that can leave Dante exposed for quick attack if timed incorectly, but are devastating when they land. Also, Arbiter has some pretty powerful long distance attacks. Eryx is more complex than Arbiter, since timing is everything with it. It can be quicker than Arbiter, but at the same time weaker. The catch is that every attack is chargeable and has three levels of power, last one being among the most powerful moves you can perform in the game. It has also some area-of-effect moves that damage all the enemies about. The key to quick and cool destruction of your enemies is not only learning their weaknesses, but also forming combos with different weapons in quick succession. Every weapons has a moment after first two basic attacks, when if you wait until the weapons shines a little and then proceed with another basic attack, another combo starts that is more powerfull, more specific or has a different effect. The great thing about this that you can use to your advantage is that in the moment of waiting to start this different combo you can switch weapons and do the special combo of another weapon. For instance, you can do two quick slashes with Rebellion or Osiris and the swich to Arbiter's special combo, Trinity Smash, which does thrice the damage as Arbiter's usual last attack, and you can achieve this devastation in much shorter time that using the two slow initial attacks of Arbiter.
I also have to recommend downloading the Bloody Palace addon. It's free, it's easy way to learn how to use weapons and fight enemies, also to earn orbs, and, most importantly, it's fun, especially if you are in mood for some DmC action right away.

reviewText:
Before you read this review, you should keep in-mind that I've never played a Devil May Cry game before so I don't know how it compares to past games. With that said, DmC: Devil May Cry is a pretty great game with enjoyable gameplay and a surprisingly good story.

THE PROS:
Surpisingly good story that has a mix of seriousness and jokes.
Fun gameplay that has a Stylish" system -- you earn more points by doing combos that uses a variety of different attacks
date: and not just the same moves over and over again.\nAs the story progresses
recommended:
you see Dante go from "not caring" about anything to actually caring about everything.
Great level design full of secrets.
You unlock new weapons/abilties as you progress.
Weapons and abilities can be upgraded with skill points -- or even new abilities can be unlocked with skill points.
Beating the game on higher difficulties will unlock even higher diffculties multiple times
hoursPlayed:
encouraging multiple play-throughs.
Some cool unlockable skins.
Practice mode.
Around 10 hours until you beat the game.

THE MIXED:
Some may find the game kinda repetitive.
Some may also find the game too "try hard" and/or cheesy for their taste.
And of course
voteText: some may not like Dante's new design (however
helpfulPercent:
I am personally fine with it).

THE CONS:
I personally found the final boss fight and ending to be kinda dissapointing.
Some fights are more annoying/tedious than fun.

THE VERDICT:  8.5/10 "Between Great and Amazing"
DmC: Devil May Cry really is a great game

reviewText:
Despite the outcry of many hard core fans, DmC: Devil May Cry, redundantly named as it may be, is a good game. Ninja Theory has taken some creative liberty with Dante's character, but this isn't really the same Dante when you think about it. This is a reboot not a sequel.

The best way to look at this new DmC is think of it as a separate entirely new Dante set in an alternative, much like the new Superman ('Man of Steel'). They are different people with different origins and different motivations/  If you can think of the new Dante and old Dante in this way, as being 2 completely separate people then the character changes are significantly less bothersome.

Character issues aside Ninja Theory did a marvelous job with the game play.  The game play retains the fast and furious action of the previous games. One thing I really enjoyed is the battles areas fell much more open and larger than in previous titles allowing you to more clearly see everything that is going on. The plethora of weapons and changes on the fly are also well implemented and allow for a variety of successive combos.  One of my favorite features is the ability to try the skill before you upgrade it, as well as the ability to switch between skill load-outs between levels.

Overall DmC is a vastly underrated game for a variety of reason, but if you can come into the game with an open mind and think of it as just a brand new hack and slash that happens to share the same name, then you will be in for a real satisfying experience!

reviewText:
Good short weekend game that's worth the price of a movie and popcorn.

Game is short.  Easy enough to beat in a weekend.  Great casual game to just kick back and experience.  The story is a bit good vs evil cliche, but who minds that in this genre?

Best played with a controller.  I beat it with a keyboard and felt like I was fighting the game a bit.  Mechanics are easy to pick up.  There's plenty of moves to master, but most are not required to finish the game.  The game is a bit linear, but it's hardly a surpsise.  When you play this type of game, it's expected and doesn't really take away from the games focus...action.

Audio and visuals are top notch.  The game sounds and looks fantastic.  It's hard not to get pumped up during the early stages of the game before the newness wears off.

reviewText: Really great addition to the DmC Series, well done Ninja Theory!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I haven't played the others, but as a standalone this is a really good game.

The combat is super fun, it's not just spamming. Theres interesting combos that you unlock and different weapons you hold a key to use, similar to God of War, but less inconvieniant. It doesn't just throw health at you either which keeps it from being too easy.

The levels are good to explore, really nicely designed. The collectables in the environment attract you to them in a really unique way, and fit perfectly with the art style.

The platforming sections aren't exactly challenging but they're entertaining enough. The fast paced sections really keep the action flowing so long as you know what you're doing. I find alot of games never quite get a good balance, though this one is leaning towards the easy side.

The art style suits the game and the cinematography complements it brilliantly. The music (which is actually the reason I bought the game) also matches really well and makes the experiance a whole lot more fun. The animations flow really well with both the environment and enemies. Final kill shots, using your last attack on the last enemy, always seem to look great. The characters (which I thought were terrible at first) each quickly show they aren't ♥♥♥♥. Even with the cool guy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ at the start and that occasionally surfaces, Dante's a pretty cool guy that doesn't afraid of anything. Oh and the facial models and animations are pretty flawless I'd say, not quite HL2 but better than any AssCreed.

I am so pleasantly suprised with this game, fun as ♥♥♥♥/10.

reviewText:
(I previously only played DMC1 and 2)

Graphics: The game has probably the best art direction I have ever seen for any action slasher. Great twisted take on modern city settings and very unique environments. All this and it runs smooth like butter on my modest PC.

Story/Plot: Mostly meh, only some bright moments like Raptor New Network. The Vergil thing at the end was random and illogical.

Mechanics: Very solid mechanics and combos. You can switch between weapon types seamlessly and execute a huge variety of combos and setups. Movement has real weight and there are animation transitions between abilities. Attacks are meaty and controls are responsive. Only complaint is that grappling hook spots can just refuse to trigger even though you are clearly in range, leaving you desperately flailing in midair before falling.

reviewText: Played, completed in about 10 hours, and started again in the new difficulty mode. Good replayability, once you're done with the story you just want to start from scratch and keep slaying demons, while collecting all of Dante's moves and powerups. The game runs with good graphics without fps issues even during the most violent battles. The combat system is very dynamic and enables for many combos and more moves can be unlocked while progressing in the game. By quickly changing Dante's weapons (and therefore combat style and moves) one can concatenate long and various combos. Wven though a bit too predictable the story is interesting enough, and Dante's  attitude sure helps. The scenery is always gorgeous: you can never be sure about what's going to happen once you're  dragged into the Limbo, except it's going to be exaggerated and fun. And what to say about the music... well... just perfect to go along with the quick and vicious fights offered. To concude, a must for any lover of  the genre.

reviewText:
I have only a few hours on the PC version, but I have beaten the 360 version 3 times. So far, the silky smooth 60 fps and high resolution are enhancing the experience even further.

An excellent, genuinely underrated game. While I don't like this incarnation of Dante as much due to his lack of clever dialogue (opting for more of an in-your-face, ♥♥♥♥ you" type speech than 1-4's more snide and humorous banter) I think pretty much every aspect is equal to or better than the main series.

The art style is an absolute pleasure to look at
date: with carefully chosen colors and architecture. Limbo is a very unique setting and feels very oppressive
recommended: which is what they were going for.\n\nThe music is very high on my list of best ost's
hoursPlayed: though it's definitely not for everyone. It is a mixture of Combichrist's aggrotech/death metal and Noisia's bass-heavy electronic music (Dunno exactly what genre
voteText: but it ranges from Drum 'n' Bass to Dubstep). A testament to the ost's quality (and to the quality of the musicians composing it) is that I actually am not a fan of the genres in general. All in all
helpfulPercent: it feels very appropriate to the gameplay and pumps you up as you lay down some sick combos.\n\nWhich brings me to the gameplay. Some criticize it for being less "free" than the originals
votesHelpful: and I see where they're coming from. DMC4 in particular has quite a lot of stylish freedom in what you can do
votesTotal: and you can perform a buttload of crazy combos with cancelling and tech and all that. However
votesFunny: the grappling system and the ease of switching weapons in the heat of battle make it a very smooth and skill-intensive experience. The multiple melee weapons allow you to tailor your approach to battle on the fly
commentsCount: using a scythe or shurikens to take out a mob of easy enemies
column16: an axe or knuckles to deal some heavy damage to high profile targets
column17: or your trusty sword which is good in any situation. But the thing that makes combat so ♥♥♥♥ing fun is the aformentioned grappling hook. Depending on whether you have angel or devil weapons equipped (by holding the left and right trigger
column18: respectively) you can either pull yourself toward the enemy or pull him to you. This opens up all sorts of "CUHRAYZEE" juggling shenanigans.\n\nAnd the bosses. Oh
column19: the bosses! While they are somewhat easy
column20: they are extremely fun encounters with unique mechanics. I don't want to spoil anything
column21: but they're some of the highlights of the game.\n\nAnd so
column22: I wholeheartedly reccomend this game. If you like hack 'n' slash games
column23: this is one you should definitely try out!\n\n9.5 out of 10. If the dialogue were a little bit more reminiscent of the originals
column24: I'd give it a 10. Too bad the fanboys killed a chance of a sequel."

voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is outstanding fast-paced hack and slash combat.

Forget what the haters ♥♥♥♥♥ about.  The core components of what made the Devil May Cry series revolutionise action-games is here in the new DMC; just a diffrent coat of paint because Ninja Theory was asked by Capcom to set it up that way.  In many instances movement and attacks are more fluid and fit roles better.  No more having too many weapons that you may not use half of them (my friends and I had that problem with lucifer from DMC4).  Ninja Theory did a good job with the combat, story, and mood.  Truth is they improved quite a bit.  Yes it is (slightly) diffrent than what it was before, but I'm a fan of the old DMC and I really like this one as well.  Personally I would like to see more out of both timelines.

Dont worry about the limited movesets and protagonist being a jerk at the begining.  Soon Dante finds something to fight for and has an impressive array of weapons and moves to go with it.  Some of the dialog made me cringe, but the old DMC made me do that too.

YES the game is easier (someomes much easier) than the previous DMC series.  Keep in mind that DMC3 in perticular had a reputation for being extreamly unforgiving.

...also the ending was kind of a WTF moment that needs some type of DLC or follow up to explain itself, but I'm not sure when that will happen.

reviewText:
First off I'm someone who never played 1 or 2 but , I played 3 and 4.This is a solid game but this Dante is nothing like the others.He is cringy and fake , it seems he tries very hard to be edgy and a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ but he is not.He seems to be a automaton who speaks words and has fake emotions to try and fool everyone around him.Vergil is not Vergil either.Why would Kat even like a robot , some kind of fetish I can only assume; She is alright and the demons are more likeable than the nephilim.Backspace is your friend in this game :) Press it every time you see the robot and his act.

The gameplay is solid and very good.This is all I liked about this game.Lots of fun is what I'm having so far.If you want a hack and slash with tons of moves and combos this is it.If you never played a DMC game before you can jump into this one without having to know any of the past games because this is a reboot with a robot.I would definitely recommend this game for the gameplay.

I'm going to add more to this review once I spend a bit more time in this game.I just wanted to get this out there for some who have questions on what I think.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
As an action game nut, I had my experience with all DMCs games before this one, so I know what I'm talking about when I say:
-3rd one is still the best
-half of the saga sucks (2 and 4)
-this game is a worthy and real dmc that meets the standard of this gen.

What I mean with last point? Dante was a grating ♥♥♥♥♥♥ from 1 to 4, so I don't miss that. He is more bearable here, but is the same cocky ♥♥♥♥.

Before this one all DMC games suffer from something that we couldn't stand this gen when God of War kicked this game out of the hackn'slash action games throne: repetition and reciclation of the content. Look, I can stand reusing the enemies, but the bosses 3 times? the maps 3 times? padded backtracking that kills any sense of momentum, progress and discovery?

This game does nothing of that and also burst with style and detail. The story is pretty good, doesn't take itself seriously.
The combat is honestly, easier. Just go play it in the highest difficulty you can if you're old school fan, it still can put up a reasonable challenge, if you don't miss pressing 3 buttons at the same time for actually just dodgin (thank god they removed that). Combo system works great, feels very empowering.

So, with all things cleared, this game is better than those idiots that say I want old dante back" complain about. You know
date: those who actually didn't play it. Some of them are bitter fangirls that love writing yaoi anyway."

reviewText:
Dmc: Devil May Cry

+Well made combat
+Nice graphics
+Limbo
+Fun platforming sections
+Likeable characters and story
+Challenging
+Good amount of secret's and other collectabiles
+Perfectly made boss fight's
+Bug-free
+A lot of difficulty settings for hardcore DmC fans
+Short mission structure perfect to pick up and play
+The game length is only 8 hours but there are not repetetive any way and with every hour there is always something new crawling into the gameplay
-Ending (in my opion was a bit meh)
-White wig joke that is just a HUGE middle-finger to fans
-No lock on system
-Firearms are weak
-Angel and Devil weapon system

My score 9/10

reviewText:
Took abour 10 hours to complete the main story on the next to hardest diffictuly. tried it out with both mouse & keyboard aswell as with an xbox controller. The controller was to be preferd but that is expected. However, the mouse and keyboard work suprisingly well for this game.

This is also one of the best ports I've ever played. I cranked everything as high as it could go and still ran at a solid 200fps+ which is more than you can say about most ports these days.

I've always been a fan of spectacle fighters and I enjoyed this one alot. It is one of the better ones in recent time for sure. However, some hardcore fans of the erlier DmC games might disagree. But if you're a PC guy like me and want a solid spectacle fighter - This is where its at.

reviewText:
新鬼泣在画面上和制作上都与前作有很大的区别，可以说新鬼泣本身就不能算是鬼泣的正统续作（本来也不是），但是流畅的动作与出色的打击感配合鬼泣的招牌还是吸引了不少ACT游戏粉的捧场。
新鬼泣在操作上比起鬼泣4要简单不少，可以用很容易的操作打出很好的舞台效果，刷分也很好刷，DMD难度想打出12S也不是很难的事情，双闪避的加入让新鬼泣的难度大幅度下降（尤其是天使闪避，就算瞎按也可以躲避攻击+提升华丽度）。如果没有接触过鬼泣系列的玩家可以从新鬼泣起手熟悉之后再尝试DMC4一类的游戏。
画面配乐都是上乘，手残党也可以轻松打出的高分华丽特效，配合还算完整的故事结构这部DMC鬼泣可以给10/10.
再说说DLC维吉尔，其实操作更简便了。维吉尔的JC用手柄也可以轻松练出来，还有两个大威力低延迟的FS技能。很多人说维吉尔练好FS便可以轻松12S我赞同这种说法。不过幻影剑的使用还是维吉尔玩家好坏区分的标志吧，毕竟熟练运用幻影剑可以打出非常不错的舞台效果。

reviewText:
DAMN. Just finished playing. Let me start by saying that I'm a newbie for Hack n Slash games and the Devil May Cry franchise, so my review might end being highly subjective. 'Cause being an ignoramus on hack and slash games, it's a challenge to write a good and an objective review. But overall, this was just an awesome game, I enjoyed it very much, and I would reccomend it to someone who's completely new to the genre.

For me, the controls were a bit complex and it may have taken hours for me to get the hang of playing the game right.
But in the end, I think the controls were well designed and so were the combos that were difficult to execute at times because I'm an impatient person. The upgrade system didn't add much to the game for me, except for some essential combos and a few damage boosts. I think I wasn't looking enough for the variety the game would have offered. Probably because it was already complex enough and I kept on forgetting most of the combos constantly. So I played the game in a quite basic way, in the normal difficulty setting. Wasn't that hard, but a few bosses proved a satisfying challenge.

The atmosphere the game created was AMAZING. The game jumped immediately to a dark and intriguing cinematic experience. And after the first cutscene the action started right away, and with awesome music composed by Combichrist that just fit perfectly. The dialogues were cheesy and edgy on purpose but with some dark humor to lighten it up a bit. And one more thing I wanted to add about the music design is how well the transitions between running around, entering combat and finishing combat was made. The immersion never broke down.
The characters might have been a bit one dimensional"
date: except for Kat who you'll meet when you play the game :).\nThe story was mediocre
recommended: but the atmosphere revolving around the story and the setting made it feel better than it was.\nI also liked the wide variety of enemy castes
hoursPlayed: and I saw how essential it was for the variety of combat itself. I bet half of the development time of this game went for the designing of these enemies.\nThe game had its usual average length of 9 hours but they tried to add some replayability by adding gameplay modes that remix the combat scenes and difficulty
voteText:
which can be unlocked after completing the game.

Pros:
+Awesome music.
+Good bosses and gameplay overall.
+Immersion never broke down.

Cons:
-One dimensional story and characters.

TL;DR:
"being an ignoramus on hack and slash games

reviewText:
What a ridiculously enjoyable game. I have played the whole Devil May Cry series, and this game is an exceptional entry into the series. It does away with having to pick your weapon/gun load-out before each mission. All unlocked weapons are usable in combat.  Also, the Styles (Swordmaster, Gunslinger, etc.) have been phased out. All the styles have now been incorporated into the new Dante's combat system. Instead of Royal Guard, they added a demon dodge ability, which rewards you  with increased damage and style points for dodging enemy attacks at the exact moment. You also now have a standard weapon, hell weapon, and a heaven weapon. The hell weapon is for straight up damage, while the heaven arms specialize in crowd control. Also, some enemies can only be damaged by their respective colored weapons (red=hell, blue=heaven). That can be a pain in the ♥♥♥ because it gets in the way of fluid combat, but it keeps things interesting.

Ninja Theory has presented a great take on the DMC storyline. The game itself is beautiful. Environments are colorful and diverse. Dialogue is a huge step up from previous games. All cutscenes and voices are very well done. The new Dante is great. I never once felt like I hated his character. He comes complete with smart remarks and attitude.

It takes about 10 hours to complete the game on your first playthrough. I went on to replay it 2 more times to get all the collectibles and beat the Nephilim difficulty. There are 4 more difficulties above that if you feel up to it. Dante and his weapons have unlockable skins (the weapons only have skins if you preordered from gamestop or something). There is upcoming dlc for a challenge mode and for an extension to the story with Vergil as a playable character.  Steam achieves are a plus!
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
DMC is a fun and addictive game. Downright sexy graphics and not too taxing on the hardware makes it a subtle experience even on low end PCs. Topped with brilliant fighting style and plethora of combos to try out, this new breed of game is sure fun to play.

The mix of level and bosses can be daunting at times but once you get the basics right its just another level, heck some normal enemy (read Dreamrunner) feels more more taxing than certain boss(es). Things gets interesting when you crank the difficulty at SOS (Sun of Sparda) though.

Overall DMC is a must have game if you like slashing, hacking your way through. Unique blend of story, emotions and fighting makes its a great game to play. A must have third person fighting game.

reviewText:
This is 3rd person, hack and slash, action spectacle fighter where you go through the story and fight hordes of demon spawn on the way.

I'll start off by saying that combat system is very fluid. You wield different kinds of melee and ranged weapons, that you can combo very effectively. Basically after executing attacks on enemy, you get different kind of score depending on how fluid your attacks and defense was.

Score will award you with points you can spend on leveling your skills and abilities to unlock even more moves, combos and increase the power of already learned moves. Throughout the game you will unlock many melee and ranged weapons that are useful not just for bashing skulls, but also to get into secret places, defeat special enemies, etc.

Not going to spoil the story, basically it follows very young Dante who is uncovering his past and learning more about who he really is. Dante is same old" yet younger self

reviewText:
DmC Devil May Cry is a reboot of the popular game series which eventually had an anime based off of it. I thought it was the other way around since I watched a couple episodes of the anime a few years ago.  It’s a good thing that the game is a reboot since I probably never would have bought the game if it was #5 in a series. (I’ve never played the old Tomb Raider games either and I loved Tomb Raider 2013). It’s my understanding that the previous Devil May Cry games were known for their high difficulty but fortunately for me, DmC Devil May Cry wasn’t too hard at all (at normal difficulty).

The game world is a little hard to explain since there are various “layers” to consider. There’s a Heaven and Hell which you never see (kind of like Darksiders). The whole story takes place in the “real world” and in Limbo, which is sort of a “twisted copy” of the real world infested with demons. All the game’s combat takes place in Limbo. Powerful demons attempting to attack you will pull you into Limbo for the fight, and you can also go in through magical rituals (only happens as part of the story). You play the part of Dante, a loner with mysterious combat abilities and powerful weapons, working to take down the demon king Mundus. Mundus has sort of taken over the city (possibly the whole world) through various evil ways and the humans don’t even realize there are demons among them. Dante teams up with his long lost brother Vergil and begins killing Mundus’ allies one by one in awesome boss battles.

DmC is a hack and slash game with anime physics. This means for example that you can knock around a bunch of enemies with a single swing of your sword or launch them into the air and follow them upwards with a 20 hit combo. Like the game Darksiders, you unlock various “moves” by buying them with orbs that dead enemies drop. There’s a lot of platforming involved in the game as well, where you need to get from one area to another by double jumping around and using your 2 grappling hooks (one to pull yourself to a target, and another to pull the target to you). Fortunately there aren’t many puzzles, though there are quite a few secret items to be found. The reason I said earlier that DmC wasn’t too hard is because if you don’t care about your score, you can just keep “continuing from checkpoint” until you win. I believe your score will get chopped in half for every time you die. The same goes for using purchased healing items in the game, your score goes down. The game is broken up into missions, and you get a score at the end of each mission based on your time, secrets found, style (combos), and whether or not you used items/died. Keyboard and mouse controls are very intuitive and worked well for me, but I expect people who are used to controllers would enjoy that more.

Pros:
+Feel like a badass smacking a room full of demons around with combos and magic weapons.
+Very nice graphics including huge demonic bosses. I’m a fan of Angel vs Demon artwork too.
+You can beat the game pretty easily if you don’t care about your score.
+A lot of humor in this game. Dante doesn’t take ♥♥♥♥ from anyone and you get in some insult matches.

Cons:
-The game is still rather pricy despite being close to 2 years old. I think $12.50 is the lowest historical price.
-There are maybe 1 or 2 times in the game where you might get lost in a large level. The platforming is three dimensional so there are a lot of places to go. The game doesn’t have a waypoint system or map so it’s possible to get turned around. The levels are mostly straightforward though.
-That’s about it actually, the game is very polished despite being a console port.

Overall DmC Devil May Cry is definitely recommended. If you enjoy hack / slash games like Darksiders, you will appreciate the flow of combat in DmC. You don’t have to worry about missing collectables in the game since you don’t necessarily need the upgrades. The story is told through gameplay and cutscenes, and more or less makes sense to people who haven’t seen the anime or played the previous games. Wait for the price to drop, then buy the game!

reviewText:
Unorthodox graphic design? Check.
Excellent gameplay? Check.
MOTHERF- COMBICHRIST? CHECK!
Unless you're one of them diehard silver-haired Dante fanboys, completing this one hell of a ride is definitely worthwhile.
The game has been broadly criticised/praised for the unfitting/fresh design.
This refers to both the audiovisual side of the game and the revamped, cigarette smoking Dante.
Chewing on pizza or drinking booze, no matter; the protagonist is still an arrogant badass sporting an awesome coat and a variety of demon/angel weapons, plus the good old E & I and Rebellion.
The game feels smooth and enjoyable with a decent plot and mediocre replayability value.
If you have a taste for carnage accompanied by violent electronic rhythms, DmC is worth a shot. A slash. You know the drill.
I strongly recommend experiencing it by oneself.
Don't end up with a Throat Full Of Glass.

reviewText:
I’m new to the DMC series, and as an outsider I’ve always viewed the old DMCs as hokey and full of cheesy acting by unrelatable characters. Therefore, DmC astounded me with its intelligent combat system, engrossing story, hyper-stylish mood, vibrant visuals, and virtually flawless execution.

DmC is just an incredibly well-made game. DmC is so compelling that I started a new playthrough immediately, which is the obvious intention of the developers what with four (four!) unlockable higher difficulties.

All cutscenes are skippable, although the acting is so good I find myself rewatching most the cutscenes. Death is very forgiving, and the pacing never bogs down. I didn’t encounter a single glitch, and the HD textures make for a crisp, elegant world. The sound design is superb as well.

Basically DmC is a brilliant game that will last 20-30 hours if you desire to find all secrets and fully upgrade Dante. In my opinion Ninja Theory has taken DMC from niche-bizarro status to universal appeal through sheer quality of design. After 40 hours of play, I must conclude DmC is the greatest action game ever made.

reviewText:
Being new to the Devil May Cry franchise, I can`t speak for classic fans. But as far as Ninja Theory`s, DMC is concerned I must say it was absolutely awesome the entire way through. I am definitely not normally into the fighting genre of video games, but I must say the story and world this game twisted and turned you through was action packed, and had me so hooked I actually had to go look up the plots from the original DMC`s.

As far as the combat goes the battles are beautifully fluid and almost make you feel like you`re in a movie, perfectly stringing together maneuvers. Throughout the entire game you encounter new Demons to go up against leaving you never bored. In addition, pretty much till the last few missions you will be constantly unlocking new weapons, whether it be ranged or melee. Also earning upgrades is satisfying, allowing you to unlock new abilities and moves with your weapons.  As well as increasing maximum health.  Even with all that the gameplay has more to offer; I would most definitely consider this game a platformer with the amount of climbing, jumping, and swinging that occurs.

Where this game shines in my opinion is it`s one of a kind world and story. Most combat will happen once you have been dragged into “Limbo,” a city controlled entirely by Demons. The artwork in this game, (especially in Limbo) is stunning and refreshing, often having vibrant colors and offering a unique look. The demons also look like serious creatures, but still leaving enough room for the game`s dark comedic tendencies. The plot I suppose is more personal opinion but I simply couldn’t get enough! The thought of exploring the afterlife and the backstory of Dante was really cool, and the three protagonists (Dante, Kat, and Virgil) all have their reasons for what make them to me, strong characters. In particular, Dante.  Plus the thought that the world we inhabit could have far more going on than meets the eye. The voice acting in this game is nothing but the best, every moment there was dialogue I always found myself drawn.

Overall this game is a must purchase, the world is one of a kind and the plot and characters were extremely engaging. DMC is on Steam right now for only $24.99, which is a steal! Just to back up my recommendation Metacritic gave this game an 85/100, IGN rated it an 8.5 also stating “This is exactly what the Devil May Cry franchise needed,” and Destructoid rated it an 9/10.

These are the reasons why I give Devil May Cry a very strong recommendation!
(And mission 20 is badass.)

reviewText: One of the most underrated games of 2013.\nDmC Devil May Cry is a fantastic re-imaging of the popular hack and slash series that follows the part demon, part angel nephilim, Dante. Players will make their way through a series of levels that are split between Limbo and Reality, while fighting demons and other monstrosities along the way. Fans of the series initially bashed the game for the new aesthetic stylings that have changed how Dante looks. But this is of little consequence seeing as how his attitude has also been tweaked. He may well come across as an angsty 20-something year old at first, but as the character grows he quickly becomes a solid Dante in his own right, with a strong moral code and personality. Combat is fast, strong and fluid, you can really feel the impact of the various weapons that you will be bringing to battle; be it sword, scythe or ranged weapons, they all pack enough punch to make the ranking combat system worth engaging in. Fans of the series will see some returning faces and ideals, and for those of you that purchase the DL, Vergils Downfall" this game could be considered a prequel to Devil May Cry 3. DmC: Devil May Cry is actually a reboot

reviewText: A game that depends completely upon whether you enjoy having the power to ragdoll a ♥♥♥♥-tonne of demons and slash them to bits. The combat system is completely perfected, no real issues with the combat system apart from it's a bit awkward to fully get used to the angel/demon mode, but that is soon changed as you get used to the fighting system. If you're expecting a follow on from the other canon DMC games then you will not be pleased because this is a REBOOT. It's called reboot for a reason and there's no use complaining about it. The story is a tiny bit simplistic but it works to a good degree. There are some VERY MINOR glitches in the game, such as when there's a moment where you need to grapple a boss, it just glitches out and doesn't let you do anything at all. The music that Ninja Theory decided to implement is the best thing I've ever encountered - personally - because it has a variety of great industrial metal from Combichrist as well as their previous Electronic Industrial songs in some levels while also having some 'Dubstep-esque' music from Noisia; Noisia also provide the background music for most levels too, really good music is found in this game and it has helped to shape my music interests to this day!\n\nI personally, cannot get enough of this game: the combat system is so fluid and exciting - I smile whenever combat approaches (Just an expression of course), the music makes you feel adrenaline-pumped as it is fast paced and works to set the scene for the story behind Dante. Ninja Theory have never taken on something such as Dante's story and the gameplay expectations from the previous games, however, with the implementation of Red Orbs in this game, I have no doubts that they have perfected it and perhaps even created a new spectacle for DmC games in the future.

reviewText: This game has many qualities both good and bad. combat feals fluid and real with dantes charachter animation flowing with the atacks. Platforming in this game has inproved significantly over the others and is actually fun. The story is weak but not so weak you just skip it. Level desing and animations are amazing from the background aninmation to the active destruction of limbo the levels are fun and engaging. All of the mocking of the original games is a serious draw back to this game they are so blatant that even new people to the series won't miss them. enimies are repetitive color coding the enimies to specific wepons was a drag to the combat making you feel limited and controlled. Most bosses felt under powered and one main enimy encounterd later in the game was actually harder then some of the bosses. There is a fair bit of replayabilty. Overal this was a good game die hard DMC fans will find some majior flaws Buyer discresion is advised this is a must have at under $30. reviewText: One of the most underrated games of 2013.\nDmC Devil May Cry is a fantastic re-imaging of the popular hack and slash series that follows the part demon, part angel nephilim, Dante. Players will make their way through a series of levels that are split between Limbo and Reality, while fighting demons and other monstrosities along the way. Fans of the series initially bashed the game for the new aesthetic stylings that have changed how Dante looks. But this is of little consequence seeing as how his attitude has also been tweaked. He may well come across as an angsty 20-something year old at first, but as the character grows he quickly becomes a solid Dante in his own right, with a strong moral code and personality. Combat is fast, strong and fluid, you can really feel the impact of the various weapons that you will be bringing to battle; be it sword, scythe or ranged weapons, they all pack enough punch to make the ranking combat system worth engaging in. Fans of the series will see some returning faces and ideals, and for those of you that purchase the DL, Vergils Downfall" this game could be considered a prequel to Devil May Cry 3. DmC: Devil May Cry is actually a reboot
date: but some hardcore fans differ on this decision

reviewText:
7 out of 10 stars.

First off, Devil May Cry is a great hack and slash title. It has tongue-in-cheek humor and compelling characters. The story in DmC was original in its own right. Sure it was good Vs evil, save the world, save the girl. But it had elements only a devil may cry title could pull off. The game NOT ending in a romantic kiss was also a nice refreshing sight.

Level design and the music composed was just fantastic. I loved the night club mission. I could play it over and over, Lilith's domain was by far the best.

DmC did not get all 10 stars because of the repetitive enemies. By mission 3 the enemies are already dull and boring, sure new ones are always introduced but even they are already carbon copies; once you find a way to exploit them, the fights become easy.Also the combat system is rather janky, sometimes Dante would move, dodge, or jump out of time or there would a delay. No game is without its bugs so I will not fault the developers on this. However it is something players will have to simply deal with as they play through the game.

Despite the flaws, the game is over all worth playing whehter casually or hardcore and fully clearing each level. I recommend it to anyone who enjoys blood and anarchy.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u1xFRKAUX64

DMC Devil May Cry has certainly been the victim to a bunch of hate, some of it warranted, but most of it just nitpicky and unnecessary. If you go into this game with an open mind and are aware that is a reboot and a reimagining of the tale of Dante then you will be more than able to thoroughly enjoy yourself, However if you go into it expecting Devil May Cry 5 then you will be sadly disappointed.

The game still focuses on the stringing together fast paced, brutal combos in an action-oriented combat that system that were so prominent in the previous entries. And the game still offers the style ranking system based on how well you perform in combat. But while the game still focuses heavily on the two key components that made the franchise famous…It does make them incredibly more “accessible” to players who have never played any of the previous entries, which wouldn’t be a bad thing seeing as the game offers seven different difficulty levels, However only three are unlocked from the start of the game and all three are simple enough where you can easily breeze through and get “Savage” or better on most levels. So unless you truly want to get some form of challenge from the game you’ll have to do a few play-throughs of the game before you really find yourself struggling to chain together a good enough combo to actually feel proud of yourself when you hear the omnipresent announcer proclaim “Savage!”. The oversimplification isn’t all bad, the game does offer incredibly streamlined controls that allow for lengthy combos to be chained together while swapping through all 8 weapons and both grappling hooks on the fly without any obstructive interface or item swapping. The natural feel provided from the streamlined controls is easily one of the game’s greatest features.

Besides the dumbed down difficulty and scoring system the game is also hindered by its generic level and enemy design. None of the design in the game feels new or fresh; it’s just a bunch of dark, glum, narrow corridors with hordes of the same bland enemies with some fairly enjoyable platforming elements sprinkled in between. Not only are the designs of both the enemies and levels bland, but the main characters themselves are also both predictable, and flat. This isn’t the bias hate rambling of a fan-boy who’s ♥♥♥♥♥♥ they changed Dante’s hair color, I’m honestly fine with the appearance of all the characters, even the new Emo Dante, but the game does offer plenty of alternative skins for those who are too turned off by the emo vibe.

The visuals of the game are another one of the games strong points, offering easily some of the best visual graphics to come out of a Capcom game to date. And the game is certainly a solid PC port, during my playthroughs of the game I managed to stay well over 100fps without any dips that could potentially interfere with the fast paced combo chaining combat.  The soundtrack of the game is honestly a hit or miss based on your view of how you feel about Electronic Body Music, as the soundtrack consists primarily of the band Combichrist, I personally enjoy it however to each their own.

After hearing the review thus far you would probably expect me to poorly rate the game, but its actually quite the opposite. Despite all of the complaints and flaws that this game has, it somehow manages to get passed all of that and provide an experience that is genuinely fun. If you look at the game you can easily pick apart the design flaws and nerfed difficulty, but even with all the flaws, DMC Devil May Cry proves to be an excellent game with strong enough legs to stand on its own and not be judged based on the previous entries in the franchise….because that’s the whole point of a reboot, to break away from the past and become something new. So don’t let the look of the game turn you off, pick up a controller and play through the game on the hardest difficulty you can and experience the beauty of the fast paced, stylish, streamlined, chaotic fun that you will have.

http://noobsthatplaygames.com/

reviewText:
Spare yourself the pain.

DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME!
I tried to like it. I really, really tried. But... it just sucks. I can't find a single redeeming Factor to it.
Everything I liked about DMC3/4 is gone. Everything. The combat doesn't feel gratifying anymore, the main protagonist is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, the unreal engine sucks for character action games, the voice acting needs work, the sound design gives me headaches, the enemy designs are bad from a gameplay standpoint, there's no lock on function, the pacing needs work, Devil Trigger mode sucks, the music is uninspired and plain, the writing makes me cringe, and Vergil isn't cool anymore.

What the hell were you idiots thinking? You took everything that was good about Devil May Cry and you reuined it... all of it.
I can understand if you messed up 1 or 2 things, humans are flawed after all. But you somehow managed to ruin everything. I don't know how, and I don't know why. All I know is that this game fills me with hatred and sadness.

The only valid reason to play this game is if you want to study the no-no's of game design.

Please just spare yourself and play DMC4.

reviewText: This game is Okay, but really just that. The combat is fine, though a little boring, probably because of the lack of different combos, the weapons are okay, but a little generic (they have the exact same combos as your sword, one is just heavy and hits hard, and the other is fast and AoE), and you're forced to use certain weapons on certain enemies, but that's acceptable I guess. The thing that really turns me off about this game is the huge amount of platforming sections in a game that's supposed to be focused on combat, the jump doens't feel great, the airglide doens't feel great, and half the time there's a fixed camera angle that makes the platforming more tedious than fun. Overall this game is probably fine for someone who isn't farmilliar with the genre, and has some interest in it, but playing this game after playing Bayonetta, this feels like baby's first character action game.

reviewText:
Fantastic!
I hadn't ever played the original Devil May Cry games (but I did pick up 4 recently) but this was amazing!
If you haven't played the games, you're in luck. From what I've now read, this doesn't follow the original story so it's a great place to pick up.

In this game you play as Dante, a half demon, half angel creature who is battling a world completely controlled by a demonic ruler, Mundus. Your goal is to hack and slash your way to victory with the help from the small resistance (super small, actually... just two other people).

The game is a spectacle fighter. All of your sword moves are massive and sweeping. It's just as much fun to watch since it all plays out as more of a flashy dance with swords than a brawler. By the end of the game Dante can seemlessly switch between eight weapons all in a single combo. You may start your attack with a dash to the toughest enemy, launching him into the air with your battle axe. Then spin around and throw some ninja stars at the weaker enemies to keep them off your back while jumping into the air and laying on more attacks with your angelic scythe before bringing it all home with your lava-covered boxing gloves.

You also have the ability to turn your swords into grapplehooks (either pulling you towards enemies or enemies towards you). This makes for very fast traversal around the arenas and lets you keep the pressure on.

The levels and areas in this game are incredible. I've never seen anything like it. Also though a lot of the story takes place in the real world" the missions mostly play out in the parallel dimension
date: Limbo. Both worlds are tightly coupled and the giant monsters that destroy the Limbo world also cause chaos back in reality.\n\nAll that to say
recommended:
buy this. I played it with a gamepad and it was amazing.

A+
12 hours to complete"

reviewText:
I absolutely love this game, the whole franchise in fact. I only have a couple of resentments which can easily be overlooked.

Cons:
NINJA THEORY company name spamfest in the intro video, egoistic way of telling people how they changed every detail of a 12 years old marvelous franchise. Signature weapons re-design which can be overlooked, after all you'll be using weapons to kill things not to admire the design.

Pros:
Interesting missions and somewhat interesting story. Brilliant fighting possibilities, Vergil's Downfall is just marvelous. If you like hack and slash games, you'll enjoy playing DmC.

reviewText:
In my opinion this game is nothing short of brilliant. The level design is spectacular with Limbo feeling like a character itself, the story is engaging and keeps the action going, and the combat rewards those who put in time and effort to understand it. Not to mention the killer soundtrack that backs up the visceral combat. Its campaign is on the short side with a length of 6-8 hours, but the replay value is high and you will continue playing for many hours after.

This is a game worth buying if not only for the sole purpose of letting the game industry know that innovation and creativity is welcome and that gamers are open to new concepts.

reviewText:
A wonderful game of a great series.
DMC is for all those who love the stylish fast paced multi button combos.Gamepad is heavily recommended as one gets 7 weapons in total each with different buttons for combos,so switching between them is made easy with gamepad.
Death is forgiving and the difficulty unlocks are very good,making sure the DMC hardcore fans have a lot to play for .

The boss fights are a bit disappointing compared to DMC 4 ,which had a lot of bosses.But apart from this, a lof of emphasis has been made to normal units ,many of which are unique and have different powers .Going up in the difficulty ladder gives a different set of enemies in the same environment , which will need different strategies to ensure a smooth progression to the next level.

All in all, a good game and would recommend it to the DMC fans .

reviewText:
DmC is a good game. Like many tough men I typed a lot of ♥♥♥♥ about this game and Ninja Theory. Well, they are due an apology because DmC is not garbage.

Dante controls very well. The weapons are fun to use and provide good variety for doing combos. Grappling enemies is stolen from DMC4 and is as fun here as it was in that game. Wrangling monsters is oddly satisfying. Someone should make an entire game about just that.

Framerate is very good on my old as dirt PC. The game looks great, too. Ninja Theory is one of those developers known for great looking games and I think DmC is a good example of that. Technically it doesn't seem to do anything outrageous but the art is neat, what effects exist are used well and overall it's a pretty game.

Enemies are fun to fight. They respond well to getting hit and dragged all over the place by grappling hooks. Many enemies are color coded and only vulnerable to one set of Dante's weapons. This mechanic is dumb and I don't like being forced to use certain weapons.

Bosses are straight garbage. Probably the biggest flaw in the game. Every boss is right out of the Zelda/God of War school. Two or three very telegraphed, very slow attacks repeated over and over while their weak spot gets beaten up. After doing enough damage the boss gets visibly hurt, the attacks patterns speed up or very slightly change, and after another couple cycles the boss is dead.

One boss is very neat looking. He's basically a demonic combination of Bill O'Reilly' and Max Headroom.

The last boss is the coolest but the trick to beating him is foolish. I don't like it when a boss is completely invulnerable except for one specific thing, and especially when that thing isn't obvious. (At least, it wasn't obvious to me; maybe I am too dumb for Ninja Theory's boss fight designers.)

Finally, my understanding is that NT was given this chance to revitalize the DmC brand and one area they were expected to excel was story telling. Well, they ♥♥♥♥ed that up spectacularly. The story in DmC isn't bad but it is every part as dumb, nonsensical and populated with oddball characters and off pitch characterization as every previous DmC. Why would Capcom expect any different? Devil May Cry has an insane premise and trying to present the narrative as anything but outrageous camp is doomed to fail.

NT didn't make a great Devil May Cry but they made in my estimation the best Western action game of the entire HD generation. That's not saying much and Bayonetta, Ninja Gaiden 2 and of course Devil May Cry 4 are all better games. That doesn't mean DmC is worthless to Japanese action game fans. Go in with tempered expectations and I think you'll agree this is a promising step forward for Western action game development.

reviewText: One of the most underrated games of 2013.\nDmC Devil May Cry is a fantastic re-imaging of the popular hack and slash series that follows the part demon, part angel nephilim, Dante. Players will make their way through a series of levels that are split between Limbo and Reality, while fighting demons and other monstrosities along the way. Fans of the series initially bashed the game for the new aesthetic stylings that have changed how Dante looks. But this is of little consequence seeing as how his attitude has also been tweaked. He may well come across as an angsty 20-something year old at first, but as the character grows he quickly becomes a solid Dante in his own right, with a strong moral code and personality. Combat is fast, strong and fluid, you can really feel the impact of the various weapons that you will be bringing to battle; be it sword, scythe or ranged weapons, they all pack enough punch to make the ranking combat system worth engaging in. Fans of the series will see some returning faces and ideals, and for those of you that purchase the DL, Vergils Downfall" this game could be considered a prequel to Devil May Cry 3. DmC: Devil May Cry is actually a reboot
date: but some hardcore fans differ on this decision
recommended:
thus aligning the timeline:

DmC Devil May Cry
Devil May Cry 3
Devil May Cry 1
Devil May Cry 4
Devil May Cry 2

But putting that subject aside

reviewText: So up front, I am neither a DMC fan" nor am I a fan of banging my head against the wall hard. I tried old DMC years ago (I think the original) and it had an interesting combo mechanic but not enought to keep me involved. Times have changed
recommended: DMC has changed.\n\nAs I understand it the modes that "true" DMC fans are looking for are available. However
hoursPlayed:
I can admit I didn't touch them. I played DMC: Devil May Cry on normal difficulty.......and I really enjoyed it. Combat is wicked fast and fluid with tons of possible combinations to keep the demons at bay or floating in the air as you whipsaw through them with a variaty of weapons.

Enivronments are constantly changing between the real world and the topsy turvey world of limbo where anything can happen and environents no longer pretend to abide to any laws of earthly physics. Somebody put a lot of love into these environents and at times they really steal the show.

The story won't win a pulitzer but is more than enough to pull you through the world. I don't think I was really surprised at any of the plot twists
voteText: but it was still well done and helped me stay connected to the charatcters. The main characther
helpfulPercent: Dante
votesHelpful:
actually grows considerably through the game and my opinion of him changed from begining to end.

One thing that I acutally appreciated quite a bit was the mission set up. The game is set up into chapters or missions and each one is somewhere between 15min- 30 min on the outside. I enjoyed playing a mission or two each night and having a clear place to put the game down for the evening.

Long story short: I would recommend this game. Graphics are excellent
votesTotal: Gameplay is fluid
votesFunny: Story is solid."

reviewText:
DmC is a good game. Like many tough men I typed a lot of ♥♥♥♥ about this game and Ninja Theory. Well, they are due an apology because DmC is not garbage.

Dante controls very well. The weapons are fun to use and provide good variety for doing combos. Grappling enemies is stolen from DMC4 and is as fun here as it was in that game. Wrangling monsters is oddly satisfying. Someone should make an entire game about just that.

Framerate is very good on my old as dirt PC. The game looks great, too. Ninja Theory is one of those developers known for great looking games and I think DmC is a good example of that. Technically it doesn't seem to do anything outrageous but the art is neat, what effects exist are used well and overall it's a pretty game.

Enemies are fun to fight. They respond well to getting hit and dragged all over the place by grappling hooks. Many enemies are color coded and only vulnerable to one set of Dante's weapons. This mechanic is dumb and I don't like being forced to use certain weapons.

Bosses are straight garbage. Probably the biggest flaw in the game. Every boss is right out of the Zelda/God of War school. Two or three very telegraphed, very slow attacks repeated over and over while their weak spot gets beaten up. After doing enough damage the boss gets visibly hurt, the attacks patterns speed up or very slightly change, and after another couple cycles the boss is dead.

One boss is very neat looking. He's basically a demonic combination of Bill O'Reilly' and Max Headroom.

The last boss is the coolest but the trick to beating him is foolish. I don't like it when a boss is completely invulnerable except for one specific thing, and especially when that thing isn't obvious. (At least, it wasn't obvious to me; maybe I am too dumb for Ninja Theory's boss fight designers.)

Finally, my understanding is that NT was given this chance to revitalize the DmC brand and one area they were expected to excel was story telling. Well, they ♥♥♥♥ed that up spectacularly. The story in DmC isn't bad but it is every part as dumb, nonsensical and populated with oddball characters and off pitch characterization as every previous DmC. Why would Capcom expect any different? Devil May Cry has an insane premise and trying to present the narrative as anything but outrageous camp is doomed to fail.

NT didn't make a great Devil May Cry but they made in my estimation the best Western action game of the entire HD generation. That's not saying much and Bayonetta, Ninja Gaiden 2 and of course Devil May Cry 4 are all better games. That doesn't mean DmC is worthless to Japanese action game fans. Go in with tempered expectations and I think you'll agree this is a promising step forward for Western action game development.

reviewText:
DmC Devil May Cry is a reboot. This means, it does not have any connection to the past games, except some names and characters. Dante is young half-demon, half-angel teenager who is angry at the world. Sounds simple, right?
Community hates this game, oh God, how much they do. My opinion is: this game is amazing. Gameplay is just good, changed to fit right for todays gamers hands. Level design is colorful and well made. And story, the story is amazing, you will watch main character evolve through every chapter you play through. Everything that bugs me is that open ending.

Pros

+ both angel and demon weapons gives you awesome ways how to be stylish badass
+ awesome level design, secret mission, collectibles
+ I did no found any bugs in game (yet)

Cons
- open ending (really, this need another game)
- game can be little...uncontrollable, when played with mouse and keyboard (controller recommended)
- the community (some player are just bossy because there is not their favourite old Dante. Yea I miss him too)

reviewText: This game was just awesome. DMC takes place in a modern world that is ruled by demons without us even knowing it. It centers around the character Dante and his brother who are the only ones who can end the demon's rule. The game is a reboot of the Devil May Cry series and I have to say, this is BY FAR the best Devil May Cry game yet. The game offers some of the best combat systems in a hack n' slash game EVER. I don't think I have ever played a game like this that had such a smooth, responsive, and intense combat system. The game is well optimized so most systems will be able to run this game at a smooth 60 FPS with the games nice visuals which does nothing but help the fun of the game. The port of the game was well done but I can't say how the game works on mouse and keyboard but for the most part hack n' slash games work best on controllers so I would recommend you plug in a Suxbox Threefixme controller into your PC for this game. The storyline in this game is good and enjoyable but if you played the other DMC games you will already know how it all turns out. The game is fairly long compared to other hack n' slash games clocking in at about 6-10 hours depending on how much you explore and how fast you are with the combat. New Game + is supported in this game and it should be in more games. The difficulty in this game is fantastic and has some different difficulties you can play once you finish the game once for those hardcore fans. I loved this game and I would recommend it to any gamer looking for a great hack n' slash game and to any fans of the earlier Devil May Cry games. 95/100

reviewText: I REALLY wish I got around to playing this sooner. This is a fantastic reboot of Devil May Cry, and despite a really mediocre first 6-7 chapters, the game unleashes everything it has in store after that one chapter after another. The combat has been simplified without losing any of subtlety the previous games in the series have had, and while it's no where near as technically deep as DMC3 or 4, you can still unleash ridiculous combos that require a deeper understanding of the game's mechanics and weapon types. It's late, but if you were at all hesitant to play this because you didn't like the new design for Dante (a younger Dante, so it's fitting), I highly recommend you overlook that because Ninja Theory has proven they can handle the franchise.\n\nAnd I don't want to spoil some of the later level design, but ♥♥♥♥, they are *so* good. *SO* good.

reviewText:
I’ll answer the big question right off the bat and save some time. That question being is this a good DMC game? The answer to that is no it is not. Does that make it a bad game? Not at all, in fact it is a great game and I loved it. As a result I feel that amount of backlash and hate it got was mostly unjustified. With that said I would recommend it to anyone on the fence about buying it. Whether you are an advent DMC player like me or someone who is looking for a new experience. Overall it’s an 8.5/10Below are more detailed reviews for those who want to know more.
___________________________________________________________________
For those new to the series:
This game is a reboot to the series, not a continuation from DMC 4 or any other game. If you try to go back in the series expecting to see edgy Dante you are going to be horribly lost. Even though I do recommend this game I strongly recommend starting with DMC 3 or 4.
Pros:
>Visually stunning graphics and levels
> Fluid game mechanics and combo system that is extremely satisfying when fighting
> Variety of weapons and gadgets for stringing together combos or just fooling around (personal favorite is using the sticky dart to mess with low rank enemies)
> The concept of demons integrating into modern society and controlling mankind through media and soft drinks is a funny and refreshing idea to the series.
>Moves can be practiced in the item shop before being purchased and can be refunded for new moves. Allowing for a high level of customization freedom.
> Great amount of enemy variety
> Has a good degree of replay value.
> You can punch Bill O’Reilly in the face.
For those returning:
>	The combat feels similar to past installments
>	Guns are more viable during combat with a wider range of upgrades
>	Weapon and character upgrades are now dependent on your overall rating during gameplay making it all the more rewarding to get that SSS ranking during combos (They aren’t given out like candy but given in moderation).
>	Secret missions can be accessed from the mission menu when they are unlocked.
Cons:
>	The story is horrible and feels like it was ripped of fanfic.net
>	The humor is overly ribald and unnecessary.
>	Boss battles are pretty simplistic and too easy.
>	Color coded enemies become frustrating and interrupt combos frequently
>	The game glitches at times and causes Dante to get stuck in either angel weapon mode or devil weapon mode forcing the player to restart from a checkpoint.
>	Voice acting is subpar with the exception of Vergil’s voice actor.
>	The ophion weapon whips can be unresponsive at times during platform sections.
>	There is no lock on button meaning that Dante will be stuck fighting the first thing he sees.
For those returning:
>      Chances are if you're coming off from a past installment you'll be dropping your combos often.
>	Characters feel out of place and don’t do their predecessors justice.
>	Combo system and boss battles feel extremely dumbed down.
>	Devil trigger feels like a slap in the face as Dante doesn’t turn into a demon but rather a white haired version of himself.
>	In order to do secret missions we now need keys to open the doors that hold them.
>	Bloody palace has to be downloaded separately.
The biggest complaint I have as a returning players is that the reboot was unnecessary and that the concept and mechanics could have been implemented in a sequel instead with original dante or even nero.

reviewText:
7 out of 10 stars.

First off, Devil May Cry is a great hack and slash title. It has tongue-in-cheek humor and compelling characters. The story in DmC was original in its own right. Sure it was good Vs evil, save the world, save the girl. But it had elements only a devil may cry title could pull off. The game NOT ending in a romantic kiss was also a nice refreshing sight.

Level design and the music composed was just fantastic. I loved the night club mission. I could play it over and over, Lilith's domain was by far the best.

DmC did not get all 10 stars because of the repetitive enemies. By mission 3 the enemies are already dull and boring, sure new ones are always introduced but even they are already carbon copies; once you find a way to exploit them, the fights become easy.Also the combat system is rather janky, sometimes Dante would move, dodge, or jump out of time or there would a delay. No game is without its bugs so I will not fault the developers on this. However it is something players will have to simply deal with as they play through the game.

Despite the flaws, the game is over all worth playing whehter casually or hardcore and fully clearing each level. I recommend it to anyone who enjoys blood and anarchy.

reviewText:
DmC: Devil May Cry gets some flak from long time fans because it does some things worse than other DMC games. However, it does several things better, as well. The story is about as good as you'd expect: It's nothing extraordinary, but it won't make you sick, either. Dante is young and immature and this is the basically the story of him reaching that level of maturity you're used to seeing in other games. Don't be upset when he's kind of a punk, because that's the point.

But this is also a great game for those just interested in exploring Devil May Cry for the first time because the story is a prequel and you won't have expectations set by the other games. In other words, you won't be missing anything and you won't have to know what you're missing.

Pros:
Some of the best keyboard and mouse controls to ever grace this genre. Powerful, satisfying sense of impact and flair in fights. Top-level combos have less to do with tiny enemy step exploits (like in previous games) and have a more normalized flow. Skill upgrades are tied to XP, not currency, and can be respecced any time between (or sometimes in the middle of) levels. The unlockable content is good, and bloody palace mode is fantastic free DLC. One of the boss fights is really creative and entertaining, but describing it would be a spoiler.

Cons:
Certain action-less sections of the game are unskippable and become a chore during subsequent playthoughs. Devil trigger has been reduced from an integral part of combat to a 5-10 second invulnerability button. Dante Must Die mode is significantly easier than in previous games. Enemies that can only be hurt while in demon mode or angel mode greatly reduce your combo options and suck all of the fun out of a battle. One of the bosses takes way too long to beat for the amount of variety in the fight (none).

reviewText:
LET ME PREFACE THIS BY SAYING I HAVE NOT PLAYED ANY OF THE OTHER DEVIL MAY CRY GAMES FROM START TO FINISH PREVIOUS TO WRITING THIS RECOMMENDATION

This game is amazing!  I was talking massive amounts of ♥♥♥♥ about this game from every little bit that was being revealed up until the actual release, but I decided to pick it up because the original creator of the first DMC game was vouching to give Ninja Theory's attempt at the series a shot.  Another thing that pushed me was that a certain someone was threatening that they were just going to buy the game for me if I didn't pick it up myself, and I really hate it when people waste money on me, so.......

As of right now, I've only played about two hours, and would be playing more if it wasn't 4 AM my time!  I thought the dubstep would really detract me from enjoying the game, but you don't really notice the music most of the time while you're trying to dodge/parry/strike at enemies.  The weapons that I have are really fun to use, as they are all extremely varied.  Sometimes it gets a little confusing, as I'm not used to having so many options to dispatch enemies in a game!  It's only going to get worse as I upgrade my weapons to maximize my combos.  I've been playing on the normal difficulty, as I figured easy would be too easy, and hard might be a bit much considering I have never been 'great' at action games like the DMC series.  I haven't died yet, although I've come extremely close during boss fights!

I personally don't like the look of new Dante, but I think my game came with a preordered bonus skin to make Dante look like his old self, and I'm really happy they included that with the game!  He still reverts to his old self during cutscenes, but it doesn't really matter that much as I don't really care about the story (since it seems really dumb).  The combat is really the highlight for me, and I'm really surprised at how well-made this game is considering it's out for console systems as well.  One of my IRL friends told me that they actually designed the game for PC (as the framerate is actually capped on the console version), and I would believe them considering how smoothly the game is running on my 2-3 year old machine!  I'm running everything at max with vsync@120hz and have only noticed tearing during some cutscenes, although that's incredibly minor (since the game runs pretty flawlessly during actual gameplay).  The environment is absolutely stunning from what I've come across thus far, and I'm excited to explore more of the game later!  I haven't even unlocked every available weapon yet, so I'm extremely excited to experiment with what combos I can create using all the techniques and weapons are available.

I think this game is going to be really great just from judging what I've played so far, and I'm really happy I was wrong about how horrible I thought this game was going to be after following its development for so long.

As someone who has never completed a Devil May Cry game before, I'm happy to say that I'm having a blast playing through this one, and fully plan to beat this (eventually)!  Pick this up if you're looking to have fun with an action game!

Also I'm playing this with a 360 controller, so I have no idea how different it would be on keyboard/mouse!!  IF YOU PLAY GAMES LIKE THESE ON PC, YOU SHOULD REALLY INVEST IN A WIRED 360 CONTROLLER (if you don't have one by now).
