reviewText:
Fantastic!
I hadn't ever played the original Devil May Cry games (but I did pick up 4 recently) but this was amazing!
If you haven't played the games, you're in luck. From what I've now read, this doesn't follow the original story so it's a great place to pick up.

In this game you play as Dante, a half demon, half angel creature who is battling a world completely controlled by a demonic ruler, Mundus. Your goal is to hack and slash your way to victory with the help from the small resistance (super small, actually... just two other people).

The game is a spectacle fighter. All of your sword moves are massive and sweeping. It's just as much fun to watch since it all plays out as more of a flashy dance with swords than a brawler. By the end of the game Dante can seemlessly switch between eight weapons all in a single combo. You may start your attack with a dash to the toughest enemy, launching him into the air with your battle axe. Then spin around and throw some ninja stars at the weaker enemies to keep them off your back while jumping into the air and laying on more attacks with your angelic scythe before bringing it all home with your lava-covered boxing gloves.

You also have the ability to turn your swords into grapplehooks (either pulling you towards enemies or enemies towards you). This makes for very fast traversal around the arenas and lets you keep the pressure on.

The levels and areas in this game are incredible. I've never seen anything like it. Also though a lot of the story takes place in the real world" the missions mostly play out in the parallel dimension
date: Limbo. Both worlds are tightly coupled and the giant monsters that destroy the Limbo world also cause chaos back in reality.\n\nAll that to say
recommended:
buy this. I played it with a gamepad and it was amazing.

A+
12 hours to complete"

reviewText:
TL:DR - 7.5/10 for fun action gameplay, easy mechanics, and an okay storyline. Worth it if on sale, up to you at full price.

I have just finished my playthrough of both the base game and the DLC Fall of Vergil gameplay on Devil Hunter difficulty. DMC has the humor and I feel they got Dante's cocky demeanor down to perfection. The story was pretty good, if not predictable at times but you don't really play games like these for stories, you play them to feel like a badass. In this case, the game delivers. The game is kind of short, as I have beaten the base game in 8 hours and the DLC in about 2.

Dante is given his trusty Ebony and Ivory, his sword Rebellion, and four other types of weapons. Two of them being more power based and the other two being more speed based. You can switch between the four extra weapons seamlessly for some pretty awesome combos. I found it pretty easy to get at least an S rating on combos once I got the controls down and I got them down really quickly. It's easy to understand how each weapon works and you're pretty much limited by your creativity when it comes down to putting combos together. Since I played the game on Devil Hunter (normal), it wasn't that hard to beat but still challenging enough to feel satisfied when you get an SSS combo score. No doubt the harder difficulties will provide some fun and frustration.

Fall of Vergil really pales in comparison. I know it's a DLC so it won't have as much content but will Vergil you're only given Yamato and his Illusion powers. Don't get me wrong, Vergil's a badass and it was rewarding to kick ♥♥♥ with him once I got used to him. The difference is that while Dante has an arsenal of weapons that allow him to handle multiple enemies at once allowing you to be a powerhouse, Vergil was more limited and I felt you have to be more evasive and strike more precisely. That said, his demon form is pretty cool and is a little more dynamic than Dante. Still it doesn't beat being able to switch multiple weapons and going to town on those demons.

The only way this game could have been better is a longer game and more interesting characters.

Do I recommend this game at full price? As cheap as I am, I would say no. But I feel I'm an outlier of the average consumer when it comes to assessing the worth of games. I'm incredibly cheap and I only ever really buy during sales. That said, I bought this game during the Summer Sale and by that I would absolutely recommend getting this game.

I say wait for a sale and then get it. But that's my personal opinion.

reviewText:
I will preface this with a statement:

I wouldn't call myself an avid DmC fan. I have the other games. I've played them, and they were fun. Heard varying opinions of this game and got it on sale to see for myself. First off, a lot of the people saying its horrible and the spawn of Satan and the like are wrong. Kinda. It has its good points, it has its bad points, and it has quite a few just plain mediocre points, so I'll try and be as fair as I can here.

(Warning. Warning. A new Wall of Text approaches.)

First off, how does it play? Decently. Combat is nice and smooth, flows really well, but... it's not at all that difficult. Some of it just gets kind of silly too. Once the grab mechanics got introduced, I almost immediately figured out how to just return to my home planet without much difficulty at all. While things like this are usually possible, in this game it seems rather hilariously simple to discover and then spam them to your heart's content. Also, Dante's devil trigger is kind of silly. He freezes time, which would normally have me :D'ing, but then he flings everyone up into the air where they are annoying to hit, invalidating every single ground combo I have, basically. Anyway, I didn't find quite as much depth or challenge to the fighting mechanics as I would nessecarily like, but this is coming from a guy who loves Dark Souls and plays everything on the hardest difficulty he can, so my definition of challenge is a bit different from most casual players. Aside from being somewhat more simplistic than I expected, however, there isn't much of anything you can call a fault in the combat. It's pretty looking, very smooth, and kind of mediocre, really.

Plot? Look, let's be honest here, no one plays the original DMC games for the plot. That was one of the many mistakes they made with 2, in fact. That said, unlike the original games, which were trying harder to be entertaining that tell a really detailed story, this one has one. A rather large one that I'm not really a fan of. However, all matters of opinion aside for the most unbiased review, it's mostly another Eh" from me. Despite usually being an obsessive gamer who watches every cutscene and searches for all the little details etc. I just wasn't that interested in the plot. It's there

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u1xFRKAUX64

DMC Devil May Cry has certainly been the victim to a bunch of hate, some of it warranted, but most of it just nitpicky and unnecessary. If you go into this game with an open mind and are aware that is a reboot and a reimagining of the tale of Dante then you will be more than able to thoroughly enjoy yourself, However if you go into it expecting Devil May Cry 5 then you will be sadly disappointed.

The game still focuses on the stringing together fast paced, brutal combos in an action-oriented combat that system that were so prominent in the previous entries. And the game still offers the style ranking system based on how well you perform in combat. But while the game still focuses heavily on the two key components that made the franchise famous…It does make them incredibly more “accessible” to players who have never played any of the previous entries, which wouldn’t be a bad thing seeing as the game offers seven different difficulty levels, However only three are unlocked from the start of the game and all three are simple enough where you can easily breeze through and get “Savage” or better on most levels. So unless you truly want to get some form of challenge from the game you’ll have to do a few play-throughs of the game before you really find yourself struggling to chain together a good enough combo to actually feel proud of yourself when you hear the omnipresent announcer proclaim “Savage!”. The oversimplification isn’t all bad, the game does offer incredibly streamlined controls that allow for lengthy combos to be chained together while swapping through all 8 weapons and both grappling hooks on the fly without any obstructive interface or item swapping. The natural feel provided from the streamlined controls is easily one of the game’s greatest features.

Besides the dumbed down difficulty and scoring system the game is also hindered by its generic level and enemy design. None of the design in the game feels new or fresh; it’s just a bunch of dark, glum, narrow corridors with hordes of the same bland enemies with some fairly enjoyable platforming elements sprinkled in between. Not only are the designs of both the enemies and levels bland, but the main characters themselves are also both predictable, and flat. This isn’t the bias hate rambling of a fan-boy who’s ♥♥♥♥♥♥ they changed Dante’s hair color, I’m honestly fine with the appearance of all the characters, even the new Emo Dante, but the game does offer plenty of alternative skins for those who are too turned off by the emo vibe.

The visuals of the game are another one of the games strong points, offering easily some of the best visual graphics to come out of a Capcom game to date. And the game is certainly a solid PC port, during my playthroughs of the game I managed to stay well over 100fps without any dips that could potentially interfere with the fast paced combo chaining combat.  The soundtrack of the game is honestly a hit or miss based on your view of how you feel about Electronic Body Music, as the soundtrack consists primarily of the band Combichrist, I personally enjoy it however to each their own.

After hearing the review thus far you would probably expect me to poorly rate the game, but its actually quite the opposite. Despite all of the complaints and flaws that this game has, it somehow manages to get passed all of that and provide an experience that is genuinely fun. If you look at the game you can easily pick apart the design flaws and nerfed difficulty, but even with all the flaws, DMC Devil May Cry proves to be an excellent game with strong enough legs to stand on its own and not be judged based on the previous entries in the franchise….because that’s the whole point of a reboot, to break away from the past and become something new. So don’t let the look of the game turn you off, pick up a controller and play through the game on the hardest difficulty you can and experience the beauty of the fast paced, stylish, streamlined, chaotic fun that you will have.

http://noobsthatplaygames.com/

reviewText:
Rin's Review for DmC: Devil May Cry!I love it.
Okay so lets get started shall we? This game is just wow, and it leaves me spechless. I honeslty just love everything about it. Something you people reading should know before I get started is that this is the first game I have played in this franchise.
The story itself just has me so involved that I can't stop playing it because one thing leads to the next and then some big plot twist happens, and off you go again. It's not just the story that keeps me playing though, there's also an amazing amout of art put into it (if you look at the concept art) which adds it's own beauty to the game.
The combat in this game should not be take lightly. Much like the story and art there is depth to it, as well as a cetian skill of timing attacks and doges. When you start playing you have a basic sword and two pistols, which can be upgraded as well as you own (Dante's) abilitys such as jumping and other things. Upon fighting your first demon you aquire another weapon (A demon side weapon). You get two sides of weapons as well as your normal sword and two guns, you have demons weapons and angel weapons. After your second demon kill you get your first angel weapon (a sythe) continue through the game to get more weapons (these weapons can be upgraded as well).
Now for the not so fun part of tell you guys what I don't really enjoy about the game. Some of the controls are a bit wonky, for example if you're using your angel grapple at some points it will just stop and you'll fall or it wont read your click and you'll fall. Doging can be a bit buggy as well, like if someone counters your attack and you try to doge it sometimes won't read and you'll take the damage instead of doging. Aside from that the game is amazing!]
~ Thanks for reading my review of DmC: Devil May Cry"!"

reviewText: DMC: Devil May Cry is a reboot of the old Devil May Cry series. Lots of controversy has been had over Dante's new look, but I personally never really cared since I have never played any other DMC game (even though I eventually planned to since the  Spectacle fighter sub-genre is my favorite game genre). Now this game is a very fun spectacle fighter that lasts about 8-10 hours with the Vergil DLC adding another hour or two. Now the story in this game isnt very strong, but it is good enough to keep you invested. The combat in this game is amazing and very different to that of other spectacle fighters like Ninja Gaiden or God of War. You can switch weapons mid swing from a sword to an axe to a scythe. There are a total of 8 weapons and they are all very fun to use. The bosses are also a ton of fun to fight and can give you a challenge, especially the final boss. In my opinion the final boss in this game is one of the best final bosses in any game I've played so far. He legitimately feels like you equal and the area around you changes as you fight him and he is not easy, but not hard either. More games should take notes and make bosses more like DMC's final boss. Overall this game gets a 9/10 and is very fun and the story is decent and I highly recommend you play it if you like hack and slash games.

reviewText: I like to keep my reviews short and sweet, and I'll keep to that. DMC is a game with a pretty simple, but likeable story, decent characters and development, a good twist, excellent writing, and incredible combat. The game has fast, aggressive combat with weapons that are easily switched in an instant, and awesome combos. There is also great design, with really cool level design, bright colors, and really good indicators during combat. The game can also be pretty challenging sometimes, if you're looking for that. Overall, this game is wickedly fun, and I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
A game with much controversy surrounding its release due to both the stylistic change and the developer's confrontational and punk-like attitude.

The result, while not being the pinnacle of hack and slash/spectacle fighters that one of its predecessors was (DMC3), still comes off as very enjoyable and even addictive at times.

Starting with the bad, the fighitng system has been simplified from past releases. Gone are the variety of styles and in their place two new types of weapons are available by holding down each of the triggers. Each weapon type has in turn two sub weapons that behave differently.

This doesn't mean that this is a Fisher-Price, nursing school fighter. The game still requires skillful and deliberate actions in order to be able to deliver a standing ovation worthy, class A demon spanking. It's just that, in what i guess was, an attempt to trim some of the franchise's fat the devs cut off some of the meat as well and this in turn hurt both the gameplay factor and the overall longevity of the title.

Another drawback is that there is no visual indicator for the targeting system so focusing on different opponents and prioritizing your targets feels more clunky.

Finally the point system feels off as it awards more points the more enemies you hit in one blow or the more hits you deliver in a short ammount of time rather than handsomely rewarding precise actions like countering hits.  This in turn makes combat feel more spammy and offense-based rather than the taunting"
date:
bursty type of combat in previous DMCs.

From the above you'd guess that i don't like DmC?

Well you couldn't be more wrong.

First of all the level design in this and level variety in particular is one of the best of the series so far
hoursPlayed:
and the News Network stealing the show.

I really liked the punk/pop/street culture based style of the visuals as well.

The fighting while simplified as mentioned above is still very satisfying and fun to play and the angel/demon based mechanics
voteText: aside from a cool nod to Dante's duality as a character
helpfulPercent:
are well implemented allowing you to pull off every move imaginable on the fly.

Opting for including platforming rather than puzzles that slow down the pacing was a solid decision on the dev's part imo. It just keeps the game flowing better.

The game's story bears strong similarities to J.Carpenter's "They Live". Personally i found it enjoyable yet nothing groundbreaking given that it's a concept that i was already familiar with through said film.

Character performances are solid as well with Mundus's standing out for me.
The only sour note in that department was that Dante's one liners come off as forced and "wooden" at times.

I also liked the soundtrack as well but i realize that given the niche of the genre (Electro/Industrial) it won't be for everybody.

On the technical side of things QLOC have done a terrific job making this game look spectacular while mainting very high fps and motion fluidity on max settings
votesHelpful: resulting in this being one of the best uses of UE3 to date imo.\n\nOverall
votesTotal: a very fun to play H&S title

excellent for newcomers to the genre as well as those that want to rekindle their interest in spectacle fighters.

reviewText:
If you liked the original Devil May Cry series, prepare to be disappointed.

Rubbish combat system:

1) Hold left trigger or right trigger to use either weapon, just remember to let go of them when you wanna use your UNDERPOWERED ebony and ivory
2) No lock on, making combat even more sloppy and more about button tap rhythms
3) Specific weapons for specific enemies, have fun using the right and left trigger!
4) Despite all the flaws with the combat, you will rack up a high stylish rank with ease!

Terrible story/characters:

1) Dante is a brooding arrogant teen, not a slightly camp and charmingly arrogant badass.
2) Story is REALLY cliché, Dante is now a half angel, half demon (snore)
3) THE CORPORATIONS, DEMONS, HURRRR
4) Characters take themselves seriously like in every sub-par disaster film from hollywood

Don't buy this game if you have a fondness of the Devil May Cry series, I beg you. If you were born at the end of the nineties or later, you may like this game as you have probably been critical of games for far less time than my cynical self.

reviewText:
First, I won't call this a port since realease date is nearly the same with PS3/X360 version.

It was built from Unreal Engine 3, which is (I think) very lightweight even for my old laptop (i3 2.33GHz, 4GBs RAM, nVIDIA 520MX 1GB).

- Great controller support, I recommend using x360ce for the best performance on any gamepads.
- I haven't played any DMC games before, so this one for me is a blast. Various combo styles and significant number of weapons.
- Newbie-friendly. Why? The game saves itself in certain checkpoints, the story is divided into 20 chapters. If you completed the game and want to play it again, you can choose which chapter to do so within main menu.
- Badass characters.
- High replay value.
- You should get Vergil's Downfall too. Very good DLC at a so-so price.

Well, that's it. The only downside is that there're not many options for graphic and sound.

reviewText:
A good game for the non DMC series fanatic (And if you are then you are probably off cursing Ninja Theory and Capcom somewhere on a message board in japan). Most of the negativity for this game comes from previous DmC fans who absolutely refuse change. I have personally been playing Dmc since the original (have a copy in my desk right next to me :cwat:) The only one I haven't played is 2. That being said yeah, It's different, but it is truly an enoyable hack n' slash action game.

Pros:
-Surprisingly decent storyline, Not Squeenix quality... But good enough.

-Combat: Good 8/10, It has a wider range of weapons that can be used creatively and fit better to a play style resulting in enjoyable combat. I have my complaints some of them being that the devil trigger is now a next to useless feature and the guns are even less effective as combat tools as they were... be that as it may, the melee combat is superb.

-Gameplay: 7/10 Above average, The smooth gameplay is ridged with average linear level design giving you deja vu 20 times before the end of the mission, and the difficulty is definitely easier (I remember the days when you had to work to get the double jump ability), but overall the gameplay is nice and the interaction and dynamics of the levels make it a positive experience.

-Art: 8.75/10 Goodish Great, Grafitti is not really my style, however the art was fantastically done. Much brighter than past games and much more colorful. While some people like the pure gothic artistry of old, I prefer not to stare at grey walls for an entire 31 hr story based game. In game graphics are good quality.

Cons

-Character Development: Let's just say this dante, while at times can have good character enlightenment, is mostly a 15 year old kid who just filled out his profanity lexicon. The bad boy" theme is way too overdone to the point that it is a pile of swearing and rude gestures on top of an ego obssessed frat boy. I found myself more interested in the development of the side/main character Kat. I'm not going to start on Virgil because spoilers however potential was lost.



Middle Ground:

-Music: While not my choice
date: there was still some death metal battle themes and that's all I expected.\n\ntl;dr It's a good game
recommended: pick it up on a sale for some good old fashion hack n' slash fun"

reviewText:
Without touching on the stupid story, cause this isn't the focus:

- The combat is weak as hell. At first glance it seems alright and similar enough to classic DMC, but enemies are incredibly easy to juggle forever - playing this game on Son of Sparda difficulty (the one right before Dante Must Die) is equivalent to playing DMC3 on normal. The game tries to create challenge by putting in enemies that can only be hit by one type of weapon (a very annoying mechanic that goes against the basic concept of the game) or facing you up against really annoying enemies that take way too much effort to open up for attacks at all (do the chainsaw guys seriously need to enter a Hyperarmor state every 5 seconds??). Even DMC3 had its enemy design pitfalls but DmC really becomes just annoying

- Why is the game so easy?? The encounter design is mostly a joke, the bosses are all gimmicks with nothing interesting to them. DMC3 had a lot of crummy bosses, DMC4 fell short on making them interesting beyond the devilbringer interactions - they're both vastly superior to what this game got. The final boss is a retread of DMC3s final boss except its incredibly pathetic in comparison. Good summary for the game in general

- Instead of any sort of interesting level design all this game has is dumb artsy concepts interspersed with copy pasted hallways and floating platforms to spend another hour platforming on. Instead of exploring an ancient demon structure like in 3 you now get to grapple onto blue press button" prompts while impact fonts get shoved in your face and the game tries to make you go Wow!!! via some or other stupid manner of bombast that just makes the whole fighting arena look like ♥♥♥♥ (the disco is especially unreadable and offensive to the eyes)

- Constantly breaks up the flow of the game by making you platform. Why so much platforming. What the ♥♥♥♥. Also constantly shoves cutscenes in your face
date: why is there a shot of dantes eyes every time some demons spawn. DMC usually was nice enough to reserve cutscenes for the start and end of missions
recommended: and bossfights.\n\n- For how the game trys to be a reboot they doubledown on the devilbringer

reviewText:
This game was my first Devil May Cry ever. I know that some people prefer the old ones but I really do not care, because this game gave me everything I wanted to get: non-stop action, badass fights, and an epic story.
If all of this is not enough, this PC version is very well optimized, I can run everything at max., with my laptop that is far from being the most powerful machine on this planet.

The game also gives you some real challenges and includes unlockable outfits and hidden missions. Also, I did not have any bug.

Conclusion: buy it right now!

This Ladies and Gentlemen... is a Masterpiece !

Ninja Theory did an awsome Job here:
- great storyline

reviewText:
I think this game gets many bad reviews from the DMC community because of the 'New Dante.' I have not played the older games, but I have watched DMC3 and the anime. I understand where they are coming from...

BUT this is a GAME review, not a Dante review!

I don't use any controller plugin, so combat was somewhat funky getting used to. After remapping the Angel and Demon weapons to my mouse, my experience was definitely changed for the better.

Combat felt rewarding, and it would get to the point I wish I could fight enemies endlessly (Bloody Palace DLC).

The story was good, but the dialogue could have used a bit of a touch-up. There were many scenes I was left thinking
Well OK then!"
But viewing this game as a separate universe from the originals
date: I thought it fit well to the characters.\n\nThere are several difficulties to replay the story on
recommended: and a slew of upgrades to purchase for Dante's Weapons.\n\nFor those butthurt about the new Dante
hoursPlayed: it's time to move on.\n\n8/10"

reviewText:
Well, first of all I play in Nephilim (hard mode) and the AI is so poor they wait you kill their friends to start come in the melee too, it makes fights sleepy and lacking of intensity since you almost don't have to escape, and well, if you die, who cares? You just start again with full life, indeed, it's cheaper to die than buy health, it's the first game rewarding death.

Secondly, the plateforme system is so badly done it brings you years back in the past, especially after release of tomb raider 2013 that made plateforme goes smooth for once or regret former prince of persia. Décors are poor, the one of the nighclub level will ask you to play without sound and with sunglasses.

Some items are useless like half of the weapons, and fact Dante became a half-angel/half-demon, well why not but charm was justly he was half demon only but this is not the problem. So far, the story could be interesting, taking in, but gameplay really makes regret former Devil May Cry 4 and the others, Dante's character is very well done, Vergil is a pleasure to see in another side but this game lack of greatness. We are fighting the demon king and we have to break in poor places like a nightclub, underground bases...

It's sad they aimed for 12-15y old people cause despite some ideas are nice : demons controls medias and junks to sleep us but the boss are very easy to fight and you don't feel yourself like in a war against demons, just again a little mafia boss somewhere in the city ruling few clubs with a system of move that makes looks princes of persias like oversmooth games. They tried to make it in a fashion period where devils had to be hyped, modernized like the Castlevania 2 hard fail, but it just doesn't work or as a cover, until it brings you in a real big game with decorums, darkness and cynism.

Ok, nowadays it looks cool to say some game is nice just because of the name especially helped trough bad games journalists, but this one is honnestly too much unfinished and badly done (one level decor is only colored cube you jump one, making looks like mgs ps1 training session for sober and well made) to be really granted as a good game despite some good ideas. I liked Tomb raider 2013 reboot but this one is really not a good thing.

reviewText: about 7 hours to beat. I played it on the normal mode(it was not that challenging, may want to consider hard mode if you want a serious challenge). It is an action game. There was a bit of platforming but nothing terrible. The fighting is very entertaining because you are always switching weapons to keep your combo grade rising. The story was good. It had a few laughs in it. Certain enemies were weak to certain moves from specific weapons which was very neat. It had puzzle elements on many of the bosses and used floating text like in splinter cell conviction to send messages your way. The music was just there, not memorable but not bad. Whenever you filled your combo grade to S/SS/SSS an announcer chimed and voiced the grade out(It was a very good effect). The game was really solid. Did I mention the fighting was fun?\n\n9/10 HIGH RECOMMENDED

reviewText: I am new to the DmC franchise, so I don't have an opinion on this game as a sequel.  But viewing it as a standalone game and without specific expectations, I'm finding it a joy to play.  I'm not the biggest fan of the popular genre of action games with pretty graphics, but this one really stands out.  The combat, though fairly categorized as hack-and-slash
date: is very satisfying.  The responsiveness of the controls and the fluid feel of the combos make for a visceral experience that is more enjoyable than with any other action game I've played. Added to that gameplay element is the artfulness of the story and graphic design.  I was skeptical on this front when I bought the game since I'm not really into Goth or anything like that.  But the artistry on display here just won me over.  You really have to play the game to understand what I mean on this subject.  The cutscenes, the sound, the art style--everything in this game comes together in a way that makes it more than the sum of its parts.  Kudos to Capcom.

reviewText:
:::::Intro:::::

Devil may Cry DMC is a reboot that explains things in a single package instead of having to play several games to understand the DMC universe. The first thing to note is the big change of  him being half angel and half demon instead of just half demon/human. I actually liked this change as it adds more depth to the parents he had and how in a sense they betrayed heaven/hell to be together.

:::::Gamplay:::::

The gameplay is fluid like usual but veterans will find the combos easier to pull off and less challenging overall. New players will find this game quite hard if they are unfamiliar with the DMC universe and have not racked up enough experience with games like this genre. Mostly though I doubt people new to this series will find new dante discouraging in any way or the combat “easy” for that matter, in fact they will find it more enjoyable seeing as how its just as visually appealing as the rest of the DMC games just not as hard to pull off.

:::::Level Design:::::

The level design I don’t see talked about much even when they were recommending this game and I don’t understand why. The level design is pretty great and its not really the details that sell it but rather the variety in animations and movement you see in the environments as you progress through the game. Though notably towards the end this feels less and less true but it was still solid. Note that there is indeed platforming in this game.

:::::Platforming:::::

The platforming is pretty much done right seeing as you use the grapple hooks and wings to navigate throughout the levels. The platforming doesn’t get complex it rather paces itself as you gain powers and is used for boss fights also which is very welcome. Since you know I do not like demon vomit melting me.

:::::Conclusion:::::

The major two positives in this game is the gameplay and level design which for most people is enough to justify buying the game even if its on sale because we are off-put about the new story and characters.

reviewText:
This was my first entry into the Devil May Cry series and I have been thoroughly impressed. The story is interesting, but not overly original. The graphics are great and the style is unique. However as the game progresses there is not a ton of variety in environments.

The gameplay is truly outstanding and what makes this game shine. I played with a controller and the ability to smoothly chain combos together was great fun. Rarely do I replay a single player story, but I've started working through the story again just because the gameplay is so much fun.

I can't compare it to the others in this series, but this game is just plain fun. If you enjoy melee third person action games you need to get this game. Wait for it to be on sale, but you should definitely get it!

reviewText:
I've always been a fan of the Devil May Cry Series. As this game is now on sale, I thought it's a good time to write a quick review.

Dante might initially get a pretty strong reaction from some fans, he's no longer a cocky badass, instead he's something of a lowlife rebel. That will sting on occasion, because the cocky badass persona had been built up over several iterations and had gained some pretty good (if cheesy) characterisation in Devil May Cry 3.

But given that this is the game after Devil May Cry 4, it's a vast improvement in almost every way. The story is ok (in that the character development is there and the plot is solid) but never shines, or at least not in the way the gameplay does. Fighting is smoother than ever, switching between weapons feels seemless, and no one weapon is ever distinctly bad for a given situation (the game may sometimes force you to fight opponents immune to certain weapons but is otherwise happy to let your style dictate how you fight)

I think the best game to compare it to is Devil May Cry 3. Both have Dante at the start of his story, both have him meeting with Vergil, his brother but they both take it in different directions. The gameplay is better in DmC, the story better in Devil May Cry 3, but both still have the cheesy dialogue and incredible action sequences.

In short, if you loved the old games, you should love this one just as much. If you loved the old Dante however, it might take a while to adapt.

reviewText: Now that I've had time to play it away from the anger of not having silver hair I have come to a real conclusion on this game. It's an 'eh'. Hidden behind beautiful environments and a fine premise is a combat system which in any game would be 'fine'. Here the approach to fighting is entirely dictated by the game and not the player. Enemy has a shield? You pretty much have to use your grabber to take it off them. Enemy is a specific colour? Well I hope you like the maximum two weapons that will hurt them then, because otherwise you're ♥♥♥♥ed laddy. Also the dodge mechanic. Now in DMC4 there was a similar skill which allowed for perfect last minute dodging and that worked fine because it could cut through your combos and allow you to escape. Here if you've fired up one of your slow attacks (all your red weapons) and you see something about to hit you, there's nothing you can do about it. You're stuck swinging this big ♥♥♥♥ off axe. This may not be such a problem if the game wasn't limited to 30fps where every frame counts and you've got to hit the right one to get away. In previous DMC games we had choice. We could string together any combination of moves, weapons and style to get what we wanted. They weren't always successful against everything but then we learnt to adapt. Here you are given no such freedom. You do exactly what the game wants and if you don't you get ♥♥♥♥ on. Bosses have huge glowing weak spots to wail on, overly telegraphed attacks and the platforming sections weren't fun when DMC3 did it. There is no quick thinking to be done, because if you're not thinking at the game's speed then you'll just end up frustrated. I want to enjoy it, I really do. But I can't stand more than a (incredibly short) mission at a time.

reviewText:
Amazing game, strong story line and character progression. There are up to 20 levels and some secret missions through out the game + several difficulties which effect the way the game is played. (Depending on the difficulty you choose, there will be more random and stronger enemies, they will havea  different attacking nature making combat harder to predict)

The game is loads of fun and you can play multiple times, to help your interest in the game you can change the skins or your weapons and character through game completion/DLC.

For those of you who are big fans of the original Devil May Cry games, like myself, will also be amazed at how enjoyable this game is. I was scetchy of the redesign of the characters and the looks of the Rebellion but they all grow on you sooner or later, though I still prefer old style.

reviewText:
Before  any of you read this review, let me say that i am an AVID Devil May Cry fan. I have played the originals 1-3 as well as 4 and beaten all of them on DMD mode. With that in mind lets start this review. This game is REALLY fun. The gameplay is some of the best i have ever played in any hack and slash title; right off of the bat you recognize moves Dante uses in this game that he also used in the older titles, they really looked at the older titles when they made dantes combos. This goes for Vergil's combos as well in the Vergils Downfall DLC. The gameplay can be difficult at times on the harder levels but this is to be expected in any devil may cry game. i HIGHLY recommend a controller when playing this on PC; the mouse and keyboard controls do not suit this game. Here is a short list of pro's and con's about this game

PRO's
- Addicting Gameplay
- Good Graphics (easy on the videocard) Running on a HD7850 ultra with everything maxed, average around 40-50 FPS
- Amazing Swordplay
- Good Platforming Sections
- Good Music
- Decent Story

CON's
- New Dante. What can i say, coming from the older games its really sad to see this new dante compared to the old dante that was laid back, funny, and awesome. It takes a bit of getting used to new dante but still, i really wish old dante was in this game.
- New Vergil. Same thing here. Vergil was a complete badass in DMC 3 but now he isnt until after the end of the Vergil's Downfall DLC. In my opinion the Vergils Downfall DLC is much better than the original game as Vergils combos are way cooler and do more damage

Overall, id give this game a 8/10 just for the fact that the new characters are terrible. I would recommend this game to any Devil May Cry fan but i would only buy it if its on sale, which i did back in 2013.

reviewText: Awesome game with great sound, graphics, and art direction. One of the most creative and cool looking games ever. Great story and script and great voice acting. The soundtrack is absolutely slamming heavy metal that fits right in when you are going bananas and wiping the floor with enemies left and right, but it is the type of music that is purely best heard while playing the game. I have tried listening to the soundtrack outside of the game and it oddly enough sounds like crap without the game to go with it. The controls are tight and very responsive with zero delay and quick, brutal gameplay. The only complaint I have is that like all other DMC games, this has a ♥♥♥♥ load of different moves. Like 5 or 6 different weapons and each has its own moveset, but in fairness the moves are almost the same button combinations for each weapon, so switching to weapons and doing moves can be done with lightning speed with practice. Even so though, it is still easy to get a little confused during combat and forget exactly what you need to do to avoid dmg and also kick heads in properly, but overall the game is very manageable with practice and fun. Basically it is a healthy combination of jumping and dodge rolling to avoid attacks, and power moves and grappling and aerial moves. Not all of the moves are needed either unless you are someone who wants to mix things up wildly and get a perfect score of SS on each level. I can usually get an A on every level, and often a S and sometimes a SS. The only downsides I found with the game are the last two boss fights being huge letdowns. Mundis is extremely easy then when I fought the real last boss on mission 20 (I won't spoil who it is) I could not figure out exactly how to finish him off. I had to google how to do it. The game is also short, under ten hours. I got the Virgil dlc so hopefully it has a bit more gameplay.\n\nOne of the few games I have ever played where I do not have any real complaints because it does not have any serious flaws. A lot of time and care went into this game and it shows. It is bad to the bone and you get to be a complete badass and go ape ♥♥♥♥ and mow down demons mercilessly. Brutal, hard-core fighting at its best, 8/10

reviewText:
Ninja Theory scores another hit.

First off, it has a console game pedigree, you're probably best off with a gamepad. Also, I've never play the other Devil May Cry games, so this is being judged on its own.

The graphics are fantastic, especially the motion-captured animation and the generally trippy and dreamlike set design. I found myself really enjoying the soundtrack even though metal and industrial aren't really my thing. The audio reminded me of Max Payne 3 in that regard.

It did feel a little short at 10 hours on a normal mode playthrough, but the game encourages replaying and thus I'm not sure I'm done with it.

reviewText: Ninja Theory has done a terrific job capturing the spirit and flow of original Devil May Cry series, but fell short of expectation in terms of presentation. I cannot defend the new characterization of gaming's beloved icon Dante (and Vergil) because he is nowhere near as likable and admirable as his original counterpart. The plot is uninteresting, and all these new concepts and premises Ninja Theory added to the DMC universe just seem trying too hard. World and environment designs, though, are surprisingly well done. The surrealism of mysterious art in which angels, demons, and humans coexist (albeit on inimical terms) in modern times is consistent and convincing that the game is confident in what it is. One complaint that has stood out to me during the game is sometimes getting to where the hidden items are requires weapons that have yet to be introduced. I found it a cheap way to entice the player to come back to certain levels after beating the campaign and having acquired all the weapons. But in the end, the core of this game lies in an adrenaline-rushing, intense combat action, and it successfully kept me entertained throughout. I'm very impressed by how Ninja Theory has achieved such a fluid combat system that is equally profound and easy to wrap one's head around, much reminiscent of the original DMC series. Some combos are as easy as pressing the same button 4 times in a succession, and at the same time there's an endless possibility to what kind of high-damaging and stylish combo sequences a skilled player could come up with to sweep through the horde of enemies.\n\nThe DLC chapters are disappointing, however. Faithful recreation of Vergil's fightstyle and familiar movesets is impressive, but the rest of the game does not tie up the base game's loose ends. Cutscenes are replaced with cheap, anime-style black-and-white videos that add nothing to already-bland narrative. Level designs are atrocious with simplified areas surrounded by ambiguous invisible walls, which effectively makes the game tediously linear. Placements of supposed hidden" items are predictable
recommended: and lazy to say the least. The players don't take long to realize that what they're doing is essentially going through a straight-path corridor with some background that gives them a cheap illusion of exploration
hoursPlayed: occasionally triggering enemy encounters at fixed locations. Unlike the base game
voteText: all levels' environment designs look the same and are uninspired. The disappointment in this aspect saddens me
helpfulPercent: given that base game featured an interesting art direction of which I was hoping to see more. Game's occasional attempts at changing things up with cheesy and poorly designed platforming don't help redeem its quality. Perhaps the biggest turn-off of all for me is the recycled levels toward the end. It is as though Ninja Theory ran out of time and budget after putting all their effort into Vergil's playable character model alone. It's a shame.\n\nStill

reviewText: This game got an unfair amount of flak by gamers too nostalgic of the previous titles, disregarding that this is a reboot of the franchise. Devil May Cry is undoubtedly the posterchild of the hack and slash genre, and this game does everything correctly. The combat is oustanding, the boss fights are creative, and the entire game is a visual trip with its environments, cinematics and effects. Old mechanics that were sometimes frustrating like switching stances have been made more fluid. They have even made the sections between fights into very fun platforming sequences. Overall I'd highly recommend this game if you are a fan of hack and slash games, especially now that it's so cheap on Steam. And definitely plug in a controller for this one, otherwise you will literally destroy your keyboard with presses when ♥♥♥♥ hits the fan.

reviewText: DmC starts off a bit slow, but finishes so strong and turns out to be one of the best games 2013 had to offer.  The combat is extremely satisfying once you unlock a few different weapons and are able to switch between them mid-combat.  The game has some of the most memorable boss fights in recent memory (think Asura's Wrath visuals, but enjoyable to play).  Ninja Theory, as usual, delivered.\n\nIf it matters (it shouldn't), DmC is the first Devil May Cry game I've played.

reviewText:
The Good The gameplay was a lot of fun.  There are multiple weapons and different combos to use that keep the game fresh.  I know that the style meter is supposed to be a big draw, and perhaps to some people it i, but I rarely paid attention to it.
You get most of your equipment pretty early in the game, which makes the gameplay pretty deep and fun right from the beginning.  You can get some neat combos going, and some of the enemies require different weapons to damage them.  That sounds tedious at first, but makes you plan out some battes once the game starts mixing the enemies it throws at you.
Speaking of enemies: I have heard some complaints about the enemies, but I thought they were done pretty well.  Some of them are pallette swaps, (which just means they are succeptible to different attacks) or just upgraded versions that take more hits, but there are some that are completely unique and can be fairly challenging when they appear with a horde of different minions.
The graphics are pretty good, and the stages do have some variability to them that makes them feel fresh, without getting too stale.  One of the best parts of the world, are the morphing of the world around you as it changes.  Looking down a hallway as the exit zooms away from you is a really cool effect.
The game will also give you hints at how to kill certain enemies, but only after you have fought the enemy a couple of times, which means you still have time to figure out your favorite way to kill a type of enemy before the game just says, yeah
date: this is how we meant for you to do it."\n\nThe BadCombat - One of the main draws from the original Devil May Cry was that you used a sword AND guns.  Your starting guns in this game

reviewText:
I wanted to like this game. And indeed there is a lot to like about this. The game play is mostly solid. It's fun as hell chaining combos and it has some proper old-school boss fights. I didn't have a problem with the Hot Topification of Dante, and while he can be somewhat annoying to listen to, the game as a whole finds some charm in its sense of humor.

However, the overall experience in negated by some questionable level design and, more importantly, the worst camera I've ever experienced in a video-game. I'm serious, this is not nitpicking. It's broken to the point were it often negates the enjoyment you might be otherwise experiencing. In calmer, corridor levels it's just annoying when it gets caught in terrain. However, in platforming sections, the camera occasionally does a 180 degree turn around Dante while you're power jumping to the next platform, sending him in the opposite direction and ultimately falling to failure. This is never not frustating. The worst, however, is when you find the final boss. It's almost always impossible to employ the correct counter, because while the game is trying to telegraph what move he's about to make, the camera is showing you some lovely clouds and a few damaged buildings in the background.

Without these issues I'd have no problem recommending this as a great game. Unfortunately, as it is, it's the wrong kind of challenging.

reviewText:
DmC: Devil May Cry is easily the best hack and slash game I've played in recent years, possibly ever. The more you play and better you become, its smooth and stylish combat begins to flow like a masterful dance of singing blades and slinging guns. It's fast, brutal, and absolutely addicting.

This game got a lot of grief from the original Devil May Cry fanboys because of it's reimagining, but they're all full of it. No matter how much I like the original, white haired Dante, this new one is a delight in his own right. So what if his hair is short and black? His personality and wit are a pleasure to observe throughout the entirity of the story, which also is the best in the DMC universe.

Simply put, DmC: Devil May Cry is a game worthy of any fan's time of the hack and slash genre. It's intoxicating gameplay can't help but draw me into play over and over again.

reviewText:
I was always a fan of the old series. The old Dante was a wise crack and a badass character. At first glance of the original trailer for this game, I hated it to its very core. It's not the DMC that I knew but over time I felt like they were heading in the right direction for this game and I ended up pre-ordering it. I'm a real DmC fan, no matter how awful the game might be (DMC2, anyone?).

I ended up loving this game. The art style is gritty and dark (which I love), the gameplay is very smooth, the soundtrack gets you pumping (like any DMC track should) and the characters grew on me. Even the new Dante.

The only complaint I have about this game is its way too easy compared to the other DMCs. Call me a sadist but when it comes to DMC, I want to feel like ripping my hair out then that adreniline rush when I finally beat something. DMC is known to be hard and I feel like they lightened this game up for any new comers. Which isnt really bad if you think about it.

reviewText:
The Good The gameplay was a lot of fun.  There are multiple weapons and different combos to use that keep the game fresh.  I know that the style meter is supposed to be a big draw, and perhaps to some people it i, but I rarely paid attention to it.
You get most of your equipment pretty early in the game, which makes the gameplay pretty deep and fun right from the beginning.  You can get some neat combos going, and some of the enemies require different weapons to damage them.  That sounds tedious at first, but makes you plan out some battes once the game starts mixing the enemies it throws at you.
Speaking of enemies: I have heard some complaints about the enemies, but I thought they were done pretty well.  Some of them are pallette swaps, (which just means they are succeptible to different attacks) or just upgraded versions that take more hits, but there are some that are completely unique and can be fairly challenging when they appear with a horde of different minions.
The graphics are pretty good, and the stages do have some variability to them that makes them feel fresh, without getting too stale.  One of the best parts of the world, are the morphing of the world around you as it changes.  Looking down a hallway as the exit zooms away from you is a really cool effect.
The game will also give you hints at how to kill certain enemies, but only after you have fought the enemy a couple of times, which means you still have time to figure out your favorite way to kill a type of enemy before the game just says, yeah
date: this is how we meant for you to do it."\n\nThe BadCombat - One of the main draws from the original Devil May Cry was that you used a sword AND guns.  Your starting guns in this game
hoursPlayed: are absolutely terrible.  I never used them unless I was fighting the one enemy in the game that was only vulnerable to bullets.\nBosses - A lot  [strike[all the boss battles[/strike] all the boss battles except  the final boss battle  are dissapointingly easy

Right up there with DMC4 as 2 of the best hack and slash games of all time. Graphics is top nouch. reviewText:
If you are a fan of previous DMC titles, you will probably like this game. If you are a fan of the genre at all you are probably going to like this game.  This game is huge fun and I'm glad I picked it up.

-Story: Funny, and engaging but some parts will leave you wondering why they went this direction in the story at all. May it be a plot hole or just plain stupidity. Still good though.
-Graphics: The graphics and the world you play in look really good but the hair effects looks awful.
-Gameplay: Really good. Everything you want out of a hack and slash.  Many weapons, you can combo almost anything together. Definitely the best part of this game
-Length: I finished the main story and the dlc in 9 hours.  But theres tons of replayability within collectables and lost souls.  Try your best to pick it up on a sale.

I rate 7/10

reviewText:
Short and Detailed review. Don't vote if you don't bother to read.
PROS: Jawdropping level design and audio-visual experience.
Reworked but still great combat with some creative enemies.
Fantastic narrative and rather simple but very enjoyable plot with great character progression and drama (especially if you know what these rebooted versions of the characters are supposed to be like).
Surprisingly intellectual social-criticism which is the last thing I have expected.
Online leaderboards for everything as a welcome addition for professional DMC players, supporting the well known series of higher than higher than high difficulty levels.
High replay value, and longer playtime than any other DMCs, added tiny things that help the professionals keep track of their progress.
CONS: You really have to force yourself through tolerating Dante's personality early on.
Alternative costumes, traditionally unlocked by succes on higher difficulties are cut out paid DLC (some remain free).
PC version feels abandoned by devs. Context: it is a freaking good PC version, have no doubt. Technically even far superior and better optimized than it's console counterparts. It just pisses me off that despite paying for Vergil's Downfall DLC, and basicly every DLC for full price just because well, fanatism, the later relased nextgen version gets additional content such as a different, new Bloody Palace mode for Vergil, turbo mode and alternative controls by getting the focus system added back. Hell I'd even pay for the Definite Edition full price, as stupid as this is, to have those on PC. Sadly, we don't.
There are no cool weapon acquisition cutscenes.
Vergil's hat. What were they thinking?
Detailed review:
First of all: before it's relase, I really hated DmC. It directly spits on everything that defined the franchise, it's characters and design and goes straight to the opposite direction, in a way maybe 10 year olds think it is cool. Continous needless swearing and primitive talk, antisocial irritating skinny toughguy behaviour from the main character (who -by accident for sure- just happend to look exactly the same as the dev company's boss until the early fan outrage that thankfully forced changes before relase) disgusting things, replaced all the sort-of japanese high fantasy / gothic looks and the classy, elegant characters - and some of the cutscenes directly mock players like yeah you liked the old one? **** you then
recommended: among others the white hair scene early on.\n\nDespite all the hate I had towards DmC before it's relase

reviewText: I always want to play this game, but then get bored playing it. And frankly it is a bit hard for my tastes, but I am not a big action game guy. Sometimes it just seems like it takes a million hits to down some of these guys. I'm told that you need more combos, but with as much text as this game puts on screen it doesn't give you the best damage info. Also some of the combos just don't always seem to work. Again, might be that I am not used to the genre, but I sit there in training and do exactly what it says and if the thing involves any pauses it just doesn't work. Any way, the design is pretty cool. The sense of humor gets old fast. The bosses look great, but all the level combat gets majorly tedious. A lot of the game is based on redoing things too which is definitely not the best things in the world when the combat is already tedious. On balance, worth the time, but only at a cheap price.

reviewText:
I'm gonna start off by saying this was one of the best DMC games so far, and YES i've played all but 2 (no loss there). This game is so well crafted, i dont think i can really find a legitimate flaw in it or anything that was half ♥♥♥♥♥. There are three things that hit me hard with this game:

Visuals:
Let me go ahead and say that when i saw the original trailer for this game, i was as turned off as any of the other DMC bashers. I didnt like the direction they took with the character because Dante of old was such a lovable guy and his aesthetic had been well established. Now that i've played it, the only thing thats really that much different about him is the short hair and different jacket. SPOILERS... his hair becomes white over the course of the game anyway, and they manage to tie it into the story. Aside from that, every character and demon is not only believably realistic, but the things that aren't rooted in realism feel very creative and fresh. The environments in this game are STUNNING and kept me stopping to look at them constantly during my playthrough. Ninja Theory knows how to craft a beautiful world.

Gameplay:
Not much to say here because they essentially took what made the old games great and fine tuned it a little more. The gameplay is purely DMC, there should be no complaints. They even managed to get some fun platforming sections in the game that dont get in the way of the pacing of the game.

Story:
Dante's personality in this game wasn't as wacky and goofball this time around, and I am not exactly sure that it's a bad thing. Don't get me wrong, he had loads of one-liners that scratched that itch, but it definitely wasn't as comical as previous games. They toned it down just a bit so that they could tell a more compelling story... and they definitely managed that. This has to be, by far, the best DMC narrative so-far. Especially after DMC4, which was a yawn fest until Dante showed up to crack some jokes. This game's story is a bit on the EDGY side, but it's totally relevant to todays hot topics and it actually makes sense when you give it a chance. The characters feel real but interesting, where as in previous games there were always characters that just felt like flat cartoon personalities.

I'm really hoping that there is a sequel in the mix and that the visual backlash didn't ruin it for Ninja Theory, this series is in capable hands once again and I can't wait for the next one to come out. I highly reccomend this game for DMC newcomers and veterans. Give it a chance and you wont regret it.

10/10

reviewText: This game is MUCH better than I had thought it would be.  The storyline is a bit confusing be cause the first cutscene when you start a play through would make more sense to be a mid-game cut scene.  As such, the first 4 DMC games (simply title Devil May cry 1-4) should be played before this one. That said, it is a re-boot done well.  The story feels even more captivating than the original, the character dialogue is some of the best writing i've seen since Borderlands 2, the difficulty curve Is on the opposite end of FFIIIX (meaning that the parts that seem hard are hard because of skill, not some cheap boss fight where tactics are necesarry).  There are a few minor things that I notice for one, all the game play takes place in the alternate demension of limbo, where demons are visible. Granted there are angelic weapons and demonic weapons that revolutionize the god of war esque hit-something-till-it-dies gameplay.  At $50 its a steep asking price, but well worth the cost.  If you dont like the new dante's appearance, if you get the DLC you can use the classic dante's. Capcom definitly made up for their past mistake of making DMC 1-4 have a strange, hard-to-follow chronology(DMC1 was the 2nd or 3rd chronologically, and DMC3 was the first). Admittedly, The limbo dimension DOES explain how the demons control the humans with out the humans knowing any thing.  There are some minor problems with some mid-game mechanics, but im not going to explain them here as to not spoil too much of the game.  I give it a 10/10.

reviewText:
I can appreciate the complaints people have about this game.  Sure you could look at it, and then look at DMC4 and say this is obviously a better game, and it is.

But that's because it's not eight years old, and it doesn't hold to a twenty year old rulebook.

DmC did a few things right,  Made massive progress in the way of saving, weapon design, etc.

On the downside, it was also a massive step backwords in terms of core gameplay.  Sure old DMC is the agrivating kind of difficult, but DmC just hands you victory.  I wouldn't call it a button masher, but I did press one button an awful lot.

It's fun though.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
On a 10-point scale, DmC is a solid 9. I got into the series some years ago after playing the third game. Comments by DMC purists sparked my interest in this... and they don't know on what they're missing out.

I think the story is great, there's some character development, the soundtrack is awesome and the gameplay is very satisfying. I unlocked all 48 main achievements in a three-week span (about 60 hours playing and I have yet to buy the Vergil DLC) and I'm still not tired of playing it. The game is definitely lengthy and it does have replay value. Bloody Palace mode is really fun. While the game's difficulty has been toned down to appeal to less skilled players, it's still DMC to the core, and the higher difficulty levels shouldn't disappoint.

On the other hand, almost all bosses are uninspired. Only the first and the last ones felt like true bosses. They're way too static (apart from the aforementioned ones) and humanized. I was hoping for more beast-like ones. All guns are useless and a couple weapons didn't satisfy my inner demon slayer, like Aquila. While Eryx was good, it was the weapon I used the least.

Despite the flaws, this kicks ♥♥♥ and I can't wait for a sequel. If you buy this, you won't regret it.

reviewText: Although the series did not need a reboot, this is in fact a good game. I know there are a ton of hardcore fans that boycotted Capcom for rebooting the series, but Ninja Theory did a good job re-imagining Dante and Vergil, and blending the demon world into a contemporary society. I wouldn't pay full price for this game, but grab it on a Steam sale like I did and enjoy it.

reviewText:
Let's break this into two pieces: Gameplay and everything else.

Gameplay: It's pretty much a hardcore hacky-slashy game with an emphasis on good timing and button sequences. The only way to rack up a good rating is to be fancy, and the game gives you quite a lot to be fancy with.

Everything else: The story plays like a satire of current day politics. Seriously. You could literally say everything is being controlled by.... demons! Oddly enough, I didn't see any angels. Dante says some puns (a lot of puns) during the game and the voice acting isn't terrible.

But yeah, I'd recommend this game. The replay value is pretty high and having friends to beat on the leaderboards is fun.

reviewText: Before this game, I've played DMC4 numerous times on higher difficulties. So I can tell you that even if you are a big fan of the previous DMC versions, this game is worth checking out. I was sceptical about this young Dante but he's not bad at all, he still has his badassery. Everything in this game is awesome, platforming is much better than in the previous DMC episodes, it's still action packed, storyline is good... the only thing that bothered me a bit *spoiler alert* is the Hell and Heaven monsters, as you can't kill those monsters without the appropriate weapon, so you have to kill that minion with exactly that weapon, which isn't that much of a problem as they are pretty rare.\nAll in all, I really recommend this game. Wether you are new to the DMC series or an old fan, you should try it out. I had loads of fun and I still have.

reviewText:
This new Dante feels like an old friend.

I'll admit, I was skeptical of this series re-launch, especially when it was first announced back in 2010 and the first promotional image was this: http://static1.wikia.nocookie.net/__cb20120923082161/devilmaycry/images/1/12/Dante_dmc_2010.jpg

My gut reaction to seeing that image back then was You just ruined Dante and the DMC franchise." and to an extent
date: that gut reaction sort of stayed with me until I finally had a chance to try the game for myself.\n\nThankfully
recommended: the end result was far from my initial fears.\n\nDmC does a good job of managing to reinvent the so-called "origin" story of Dante and Vergil
hoursPlayed: and yet by and large once you manage to get used to the new face and very different attitude (at least at first) of the new Dante
voteText: you'll discover that the gameplay itself is nothing short of the classic DMC style you've come to know.\n\nControls have been somewhat re-imagined in a way that neither takes too long to get used to nor feels terribly unfamiliar. By and large they are handled well
helpfulPercent: and a lot of the familiar signature aspects that the franchise is known for are still here as well.\n\nFor example
votesHelpful: orbs and the time statues for "shopping" are present here. Dante still has Ebony and Ivory and they still get unlimited ammo. Signature abilities like Stinger make their return with a new control schemata. Devil trigger is of course also present
votesTotal: though it works in a slightly different way than in most of the past entries
votesFunny: it nonetheless manages to impress just as it always has.\n\nWhile I did have some initial complaints about Dante's voice acting (the lines seemed really flat early on in the game) once you give it some more time it fleshes itself out better
commentsCount: and that also gives you a chance to get adjusted to the new Dante as well.\n\nAnd it IS an adjustment. Gone is the super confident whimsical and snarky don't-take-life-too-seriously Dante of yore
column16: for the most part. This new Dante is younger
column17: more apathetic and less enthusiastic
column18: but to an extent this new attitude is plot related as well
column19: and for what it's worth I think it is a convincing way to show character growth and progression.\n\nGradually as Dante begins to open his eyes to the situation around him through the plot events
column20: he starts becoming more empathetic
column21: and discovers his own true nature in the process.\n\nI won't spoil the details too much
column22: but it was good to see his character maturing over the course of the game. And while I do feel like he never reached the same height on the badass meter that classic Dante manages to capture
column23: by the time all is said and done it's clear to see he's squarely on his way to becoming more like his platinum haired alter ego.\n\nTake away from this what you will
column24: but if you're willing to brave the initial storm and wait for the seas to calm
column25: as far as the new Dante goes
column26: you'll see this is another great entry in the DMC series. It takes a bit to get used to the changes
column27: but change can be good sometimes."
column28: November 26, 2013

reviewText: Haters gonna hate the new Dante, but nevertheless, this is mechanically far better than it's predecessors. Gone are the stupid resident evil style static cameras, gone is the need to lock-on to foes in order to effectively track them. Gone are the derptastic controls that made this franchise a nightmare to newcomers. Now you can actually CONTROL the camera, dish out the pain in copious amounts, and feel good doing so! So what if the new Dante is a derf at first? This game gets a few things wrong, but gets a lot of things right. Even though DMC5 will feature classic Dante, I certainly hope Capcom takes some notes from DmC, as this is how you do that genre properly; Easy to learn, difficult to master.\n\nI also expect classic Dante to have a retort for new Dante's 'white hair' wisecrack... because Dante would totally bash other versions of himself. (That joke really annoyed fans of the series despite that being a very Dante thing to do... which makes me sad)

reviewText:
DmC: Devil May Cry exists in a really odd space.  On one hand, veterans of the DMC franchise are going to look down on it for it's simpler combat that doesn't offer fine control or complex, rewarding mechanics of games such as DMC 3 or DMC 4.  It is a significantly easier game and there is a lot less put into the fighting mechanics of the game itself.

On the other hand, DmC: Devil May Cry offers is a refined experience that I think most people will enjoy!  Despite it's flaws when held up to it's predicesors,  DmC offers smooth combat and top-notch presentation.  The major criticism I'd offer are that the boss fights are boring, QTE-ridden, forgettable snore-fests.

It's definitely not a bad game and as long as you are willing to remove expectations for DMC 5 from this title and accept it for what it is, it's a fine game by itself.

Отличное начало года, Ninja Theory умеют делать по настоящему охуенные игры, взять к примеру Enslaved, я когда его проходил охуевал конкретно, с DmC я охуевал еще больше, все так круто сделано, все есть: ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥атый графон, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ сюжет, заебательский саундтрек (спасибо огромное Noisia), хардкорные боссы (если проходить на самом харде), отличная боевка (Darksiders, God of war отдыхают)...

reviewText:
A very enjoyable entry into the Devil May Cry series, even if not as conventionally brow-beating as the rest of the series.

Dante's characteristic bravado and wit are somewhat subdued here, and he is much less campy and over-the-top. And yet, I find it an enjoyable break by providing some much-needed character development.

While I was very skeptical at first, the gameplay and art style went through a few revamps and I was sold. When I began playing, I was immediately engrossed in the drop-in gameplay and the interesting new mechanics borrowed from DMC4's Nero and his Devil Bringer.

While a stark contrast to the previous entries in the serious, I would recommend DmC to fans of the series and newcomers alike, as long as you don't hold your breath for some of the same old.

Critiques I do have are mostly based on the style change (which I got over) and the ease of difficulty, which seems less masochistic than the more current entries.

reviewText:
An INCREDIBLE game. It doesn't give you even a moment to relax. You always have to concentrate, especially on HOH and HAH levels where you have no posibility to make mistake.
Battles are awesome. Much improved, comparing to DMC4. You can make combos without any interruptions. the world around you canges really fast and you should be ready to flat out, fight with hordes of different enemies (On high levels they require some tactic because you can kill some enemies only using particular weapon).
The atmosphere of Limbo is something that can't be transfered using words. You, literally, immerse in this world. But, actually, the story line is not really exciting.
In conclusion, it must be said that this game worth being played.

reviewText: I always want to play this game, but then get bored playing it. And frankly it is a bit hard for my tastes, but I am not a big action game guy. Sometimes it just seems like it takes a million hits to down some of these guys. I'm told that you need more combos, but with as much text as this game puts on screen it doesn't give you the best damage info. Also some of the combos just don't always seem to work. Again, might be that I am not used to the genre, but I sit there in training and do exactly what it says and if the thing involves any pauses it just doesn't work. Any way, the design is pretty cool. The sense of humor gets old fast. The bosses look great, but all the level combat gets majorly tedious. A lot of the game is based on redoing things too which is definitely not the best things in the world when the combat is already tedious. On balance, worth the time, but only at a cheap price.

reviewText:
From the very first announcement of the Devil May Cry series rebooting, to the development of this latest addition being turned over to a non-Japanese studio, a far greater number of critical gazes fell upon DmC. Luckily, the people at Ninja Theory did more than simply pay due homage to a venerable gaming series; they infused it with a fresh look at the characters, the world they reside in, and the gameplay that is the series staple.

While die-hard Devil May Cry fans may cringe at the idea of a rebooted story, it does little in the way of producing disappointment. Dante is crass and womanizing, but manages to get away with being a rebel due to his unique ancestry. After several hours into the game his bad-boy personality is peeled away to reveal a fractured individual that mirrors the jagged intersections of limbo that crash into his world.

Gameplay-wise, DmC offers an intuitive quick-switch" weapon system that lets you change between several different kinds of weapons in mere seconds for some truly awe-inspiring combos from dedicated players. Throw in a pumping soundtrack and you have a pulse-pounding game that make the hours slip away as though they were mere seconds."

recommended: the one-liners are still cheesy as hell and the cutscenes are still ridiculously over the top.  Despite what some would have you believe
hoursPlayed: this isn't some massive change in tone.\n\nOne of my favorite games of 2013.  Highly recommended."

reviewText:
This a rewrite, having spent more time with the game now my opinion of it has changed quite a bit.

If you were a fan of the last four Devil May Cry games, you'll probably love this. In this retelling of Dante's origin story, a lot of the combat elements of it's predecessors has been brought here and refined to near perfection, something Ninja Theory is very good at. However the art style and the personality of the protagonist, Dante has been changed dramatically. He is less a facetious, care free, badass demon hunter from DMC 1, 2 and 4 and more the irresponsible punk with demon powers from 3, but somehow more annoying and crass. There is a point early in the game (which I personally do NOT appreciate) where Dante wanders through a circus or fair and through circumstances a wig very similar from the hairstyle and colour the old Dante wore lands on his hair, and he throws it off in disgust.

Overall, I would give this an 8/10. It IS a great game, however some of the direct insults thrown at the older games, intentional or not are off putting to me as a fan of the series.

reviewText: Capcom and Dante got a lot of crap for this one. A superfluous decision to reboot a franchise that wasn't in need of rebooting and a grittier, almost 'emo' new look turned a lot of fans off. On top of that, many see Ninja Theory as a rookie developer that still haven't really hit their stride. Games like Heavenly Sword and Enslaved: Odyssey to the West were both great efforts that slightly missed their mark. I'm glad to say that DmC their best work yet. While I have no qualms over the new art direction, I even enjoy it, I can understand where most fans are coming from. The whole 'emo' look is frowned upon (I, personally, don't think he looks all too emo) and Capcom wanted to reboot the series with a more modern, gritty, western feel. They achieved that. The aesthetics are beautiful in this game, down to the UI and HUD. The style retains a little bit of old Devil May Cry while dabbling in a newer, sleeker look. As for story, it's nothing special. Where Enslaved, I feel, had a great story, DmC takes a step back for Ninja Theory. However, this doesn't detract much from the game. While I can spend time talking about how the game looks and describing why it's story is lackluster, I wouldn't be doing a review of this game justice. The fact of the matter is this game is pure, unbridled action fun. This new entry in the series clearly simplifies the DmC combat/combo system. DMC veterans may not enjoy the main-streaming of the combat. However, anyone who wants to play an explosive action game and feel like a total badass will enjoy this title. The combat, while still holding true to a steep difficulty curve and high skill ceiling, is exhilarating. When you grasp the basics of weapon switching mid combo and using the pull/grab feature this will be some of the most fluid, smooth and rewarding combat you've ever enjoyed. No word epitomizes the combat system better than 'butta' (as in 'smooth as butter'). The combat system definitely lends to the games replay-ability. Die hards will want to work for a better final score on chapters or work to unlock all aspects of the system by unlocking new skills for Dante's weapons. Masochists will get a kick out of the several difficulty levels above the traditional normal mode. This is something the Devil May Cry series has always prided itself on and it hasn't disappeared. Collectors will want to go through each level and play every clever and increasingly difficult secret mission or collect the many Lost Souls scattered throughout the game. A combination of all of those archetypes will find hours of enjoyment in collecting concept art from defeating large amounts of each enemy type and beating the game on the highest difficulty setting. I could truly put this game in the running for Game of the Year 2013. While the game stands mostly on it's combat system, there is definitely more there be enjoyed. For anyone who has bored of Sparda's favorite son, the Vergil's Downfall DLC is also a worthy investment. Playing as Vergil is almost a completely different experience. They do the character justice and it feels fantastic. Anyone who enjoys a good hack n' slash or action game, and anyone who is holding back because of the new decor, take the time and give this game a chance.
